The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid)
took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given that you have indicated you share the view of the Malaysian government about the illegality of the recent aborted conference on East Timor, do you share Dr Mahathir's view that Australian journalists are congenital liars?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I refer to the significant rail reform initiatives of the Australian rail industry announced yesterday by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Could the minister advise the Senate of the importance of these reforms to the secure future of the rail industry in Australia and of the benefits that will flow to jobs and industry in regional Australia as a result of these reforms?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —Yes, it is a very important announcement that was made yesterday by Mr John Sharp, the minister for transport. Indeed, what the government is hoping to do at long last is to bring about a renaissance of rail, as Mr Sharp described it. At long last what we want is a government that will address the real issues, not simply pander to the unions and sit by and watch what was formerly a very important part of the government business structure haemorrhage away.

answer.para:
These reforms will lead to the creation of new jobs in regional Australia as well as securing sustainable jobs in the rail industry. They are in sharp contrast to the mismanagement of the Labor government. Over its 13 years of mismanagement more than 7,000
jobs were lost in Australian National. As recently as 1995-96, Mr Brereton and Mr Beazley personally approved an AN business plan that saw a further 970 jobs go. During that time of course the rail network continued to decline.

AN's losses for 1995-96 are now estimated to be around $250 million—much more than the Brew report estimated; dramatically more than AN's own business plan forecast. `If anything,' according to Mr Brew, `AN's situation would only get worse. The former Labor government, in establishing National Rail the way it did, created the straw that broke the back of Australian National. By handing over AN's profitable assets to NR, they were left with no revenue from these assets but all the debts and liabilities.' On that basis we took the view that we simply cannot allow this situation to continue. Failing to act now will inevitably result in the loss of all AN jobs and, if nothing is done, taxpayers will be subsidising each AN job to the tune of $220,000 a year.

Therefore on 24 November, yesterday, the minister announced a $2 billion reform package to rejuvenate rail services in Australia. The key elements of the package are the sale of AN businesses in whole or in part; interstate passenger services to be offered for sale, with the government committed to their development as tourist attractions in their own right; the assumption of AN's debt and other liabilities, allowing the growth of new businesses without the existing encumbrances; exploring with other shareholders of National Rail the sale of Commonwealth equity; the establishment of a government owned national rail infrastructure body to control and maintain the interstate rail network; and funding for environmental remediation, $50 million, and regional assistance of $20 million. The sale process is to be handled by the office of asset sales.

A competitive rail industry open to market pressures and private sector enterprise is the only way of ensuring future jobs in the rail industry. The private sector will employ many people who are presently employed by AN. By reducing the cost of transport, many industries which were once not viable will
now be able to begin operation in regional areas creating further jobs. In areas such as infrastructure maintenance and freight operations in South Australia, we expect that the private sector will be ready to step in and take over those functions.

Staff at AN workshops have the skills to undertake many more areas of work than just rail. Industries in regional Australia will also benefit from greater efficiency in the rail service. To maximise the future prospects of the region, the Commonwealth will provide a $20 million regional development program over two years. The program will assist local economies and assistance will be available through the department of employment as well.

I just hope that this program will be allowed to go ahead as quickly as possible. I was disappointed to see that Mr Carr is making some threats about blocking it, to the extent that the New South Wales government has shares in National Rail. But I am sure that he will see the light. He will realise that the Tasmanian and South Australian governments have endorsed this package. Anyone who has had anything to do with the industry will know that it is about time someone was prepared to take the hard decisions and try to put the industry back on a basis of profitability and to create new jobs in the rail sector, rather than simply standing by, wringing one's hands and doing as Mr Laurie Brereton did in telling Jack Smorgan, the Chairman of AN, that nothing would be done until after the last election. What a total abdication of responsibility.
(Time expired)

question.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, in response to an answer given by you to a question on the new deeming provisions on superannuation for people aged greater than 55, a measure that will unfairly affect 67,000 Australians, you said:

question.para: We are doing nothing more than introducing the means test at 55 for people who have been out of work for nine months that they will have to face at 65. If they are effectively retired, there is no injustice in that whatsoever.
What is your definition of `effectively retired'?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —The requirements of people over 55 who have been looking for work for nine months mean that, in the current climate of unemployment, sadly all too many of them have little or no expectation, realistically, of getting work later. You, like I, Senator Sherry, have no doubt had come through your doors too many of these people, constituents, who feel that their world has finished because they are no longer valued by our society. I have great sympathy for people in that position, and I would not want that to be understood in any other way.

answer.para: Nevertheless, in determining what assistance should be given to people in that position, a categorisation needs to be made of in what circumstances they will then be included in the means testing of their superannuation. Senator Sherry, I must point out that prior to 1993 your government had means testing of superannuation assets. Your government chose to remove the means testing of super products at that time. I understand that the projection that your government had of the cost to revenue was really quite small.

The experience of the last three years is that that projected cost was quite unrealistic and in fact many tens of millions of dollars—perhaps up to $100 million—of forgone revenue has been the consequence. This is a bleeding of the system which cannot be allowed to continue. It is not unfair that people who are effectively retired, even if it is involuntarily, should be means tested in the same way as they would be when they are 65.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would you consider the case of a man formerly employed in the banking industry for 37 years, made redundant last year at the age of 55, wanting to work—
—Oh, put it on notice.
—This is important, Senator Hill; tens of thousands of people are affected by this—still looking for work, effectively retired?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para:
—I think I have already canvassed that pretty thoroughly, but I would
be very happy to add my previous remarks by pointing out that the week before last I was at the OECD in Paris, where members of the OECD were looking at this very issue of early retirement and the problems which are facing OECD countries as a result of the combination of early retirement, a drop in the birth rate and increasing life expectancy for their people.

answer.para:
All those countries are looking at ways that they must find to discourage people from early retirement and to encourage them to stay in the work force longer. One of the election commitments of this government was that we would encourage people to stay in the work force as long as possible through the introduction of a pension bonus scheme, which we have not introduced in our first budget but which we will be continuing to work on.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The minister would be aware that last week the Senate passed the family tax initiative bills, which provide benefits to a number of Australian families in accordance with one of our central campaign promises. When will those bills become law? How many people will be beneficiaries? When will their benefits commence? What other essential legislation in the budget remains to be passed?
—Last week was a big win for Australian families. There is no doubt about that. It was the week in which the Howard government delivered on its election promise to give two million—
—Medical fees went up. You put up health fees.
—The dental scheme went out the window.

—I know Labor is not interested in this, but there are two million Australians out there who are. The Howard government delivered on its election promise to give two million eligible Australian families assistance to the tune of $1 billion a year.

break.para: The family tax initiative bills which were passed by the Senate will give relief to Australian families after 13 years of neglect by the Labor Party. In just five weeks time, around two million eligible low and middle income families will begin receiving payment. I remind the house that this will be on top of the benefits received from low interest rates, which are as a result of this government's good policies and which are providing an extra $145 a month for families with a loan of $100,000. So Christmas is looking good for Australian families.

There is a worry, however, as to the balance of this budget. We have tackled expenditure in a way that Labor was not prepared to. We have done so in order to bring down interest rates, which we have, to bring down inflation and to keep taxation low. They are our commitments, but they require passage of legislation on the expenditure side in this place over the next couple of weeks. And therein lies a worry, because the Labor Party is in disarray; the Labor Party is having great internal difficulty.

talk.start.para: —What about you last Thursday? What happened to you last Thursday?
—Order! Senator Sherry.
—Senator Carr is in the middle of it all, apparently, and he is not even here today, so we can only suspect.
—Where was Senator Alston last Thursday? On the telephone?

—The
Age
has just told us what the problem with the Labor Party is. Did honourable senators see what Mr Cain said? He told a party gathering that party members were wallowing around, seemingly not knowing where to begin the refurbishment of Labor in opposition. He said that Labor people used to know instinctively what was the Labor thing to do but now they are no longer sure what it means.

break.para:
Apparently all of this has arisen from the Victorian Left, which is splitting, and a clash occurring between Senator Carr, who is no doubt off on factional business at the moment, and Mr Theophanous from the Victorian state parliament. We want Labor to come back
together again, at least for the next couple of weeks, in order to be able to tackle these major budget issues, which will give it the opportunity to sign on to what the Australian people want as evidenced by the election result, as evidenced by the result in Lindsay and as continually evidenced by the opinion polls.
Madam President, the Australian people want Labor to pass this budget in full in order that the Howard government—

talk.start.para: —And what about last Thursday. What do they want about that? A government member who was not—
—Order! Senator Sherry, persistent interjections are disorderly.

—They want this in order that the Howard government may deliver the total of its package. Whilst Labor is divided and directionless, I will remind you that this government is getting on with the job. Industrial relations reforms, relief for small business, benefits for families, lower interest rates, keeping inflation down, reducing debt, strong growth and business investment are what Labor should get behind, Madam President. It could do so by passing this budget in full over the next fortnight.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Do you agree with the New South Wales Treasurer, Michael Egan, who has stated in a letter to you that `it is highly inappropriate' and `outrageous' for the Commonwealth to demand financial assistance from state governments to set up Department of Social Security telecentre facilities? Do you agree, in the light of cutting $900 million from Commonwealth funding to New South Wales in the last budget, that asking the states to tender for incentives to set up Commonwealth facilities in regional Australia is an outrageous ask and that it flies in the face of the whole nature of our federal fiscal system?
—I am so glad that Senator Neal asked that question. Perhaps I can make her better informed than she was in quoting Mr Egan.
—We are so pleased that you are so happy; now answer it.

—That's good. I am very glad that you are all glad. Now let us get some information across to the Labor Party, because it is clearly in a state of ignorance. I am advised that my department was contacted by another state which offered a range of incentives if the new teleservice centre, creating 200 new jobs, could be placed in that state. It was thought by my department only fair that other states might like to have the opportunity to compete for that new centre. Now, Mr Egan, the New South Wales Treasurer, has said that our proposal is effectively taking 200 jobs away from New South Wales. Well, I have news for Mr Egan. These are 200 new jobs that we are creating. We are looking for the most cost-effective way—
—How many are you sacking?

—I am not sacking anybody. We are creating 200 new jobs and there might be more in the future. The government's proposal is to try to encourage employment in regional Australia. So the measures that we are looking at are relevant to the regional development policies of the state governments, all of which are keen—

break.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections. I ask that the minister be heard in silence.

—It seems appropriate, when the states also have regional development policies, that the Commonwealth look to the states that may have views as to where they would see such teleservice centres located in their states in the future. The Department of Social Security originally had a proposal from one state offering a range of incentives.

break.para:
The New South Wales regional business development scheme is designed to foster industrial and commercial development in regional New South Wales. The range of financial incentives offered by the New South Wales government through that program is quite extensive. Perhaps what we have seen here, both from Senator Neal but also, more
importantly, from Mr Egan, is just a cheap political shot at the Commonwealth government rather than a serious concern about regional development in that state. We are proposing new jobs in teleservice centres in different parts of Australia. If the New South Wales government is not interested in being in it, so be it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would you agree that this rather silly proposal flies in the face of the conclusions of the Productivity Commission, which says that bidding for assistance from state, territory and local government at best shuffles jobs between regions and at worst reduces overall activity by artificially directing investments to unsuitable areas?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —I would be interested to know just what are unsuitable areas when there is substantial unemployment in regional Australia. Is that regarded as an unsuitable area?
—Do you agree with the Productivity Commission on this?

—You can quote the Productivity Commission as much as you like, but the fact remains that state governments often have redundant buildings in some parts of their states. They may have incentives which they offer to private enterprise to locate to regional areas. I see no reason why the taxpayers of Australia should not get the benefit, in one form or another, of such opportunities as the ones they are offering to the private sector.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I ask the minister how he felt last Friday standing next to the most influential politician in the world and being told that his government's
greenhouse policy basically fails the test of responsibility both to present and future Australians and internationally. If it is good enough for the world's industrial giants, such as the United States, Britain and Germany, to adopt mandatory greenhouse gas reduction targets and believe that they can do that and balance job and profit concerns, why cannot we?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The profiles of our economy significantly differ, particularly as they apply to the greenhouse formula. In the case of Germany, we have not had the advantage of absorbing the former East Germany, which significantly benefits them in terms of the formula. In the case of Britain—
—Advantage?

—Senator Faulkner will explain it to you afterwards. In the case of Britain, we have not been closing down inefficient coalmines. We have the most efficient coalmines in the world. So it is in many ways easier for Britain than it is for us.

answer.para: Our position remains, as I have said to you many times before. We are responsible for growing this economy and providing jobs as well as contributing to a good global greenhouse outcome. We remain committed to both, but we are not going to sacrifice Australian jobs in order to contribute to the greenhouse outcome. We do not apologise for that. We think it is what the Australian people expect from us, and it is what they will get.

I take this opportunity to reiterate what I said on Friday. We accept the science of greenhouse. We accept that it is a global problem. We accept that, although we are only a small part of the problem in that we contribute just over one per cent of the world's greenhouse gasses, we are, nevertheless, like all other nation states, part of the problem and we accept that we must be part of the solution.

Australia will pull its weight. The proposal that we have on the table at the moment proposing differentiation to recognise different economic profiles not only is a responsible position and a position that is starting to get some further support—if Senator Kernot read the Norwegian papers or the Canadian papers,
she will know what I am talking about—but also has the potential to produce an outcome which is fair and achievable. If the outcome is fair and achievable, it is more likely to stand the test of time.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you keep talking about jobs. What kind of modelling have you done? What about the new jobs created in dealing with the science of reducing greenhouse effects? What about the new technologies used in that? You say that Australian people expect you to put jobs first. I suggest to you that Australian people also expect you to balance the competing vested interests. Would you agree that this government, which says it will govern for all of us, actually puts business first and the long-term environmental considerations of present and future generations a distant last?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —That is totally wrong. Being concerned about the three‐quarters of a million Australians who are out of work as a result of Labor's policies and trying to put in place policies that give them hope for employment in the future is not putting business first—it is putting individual Australians first. They are interested in jobs. They are also interested in us pulling our weight and behaving responsibly in terms of our greenhouse record.

answer.para: As a matter of interest, under the no-regrets approach, our performance since the 1990 commencement of this process has been better than a lot of those countries that complain about our proposed formula—better than the United States, better than Britain, better than France, better than many of them. But we will do both: we will be responsible and contribute to a better global greenhouse outcome and we will also not undermine Australian jobs to do it.

question.block.title: Guest List to Reception with Mrs Clinton

talk.start.para:
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, given that the only adverse publicity generated by President Clinton's visit was the controversy over the invitation list to Mrs Clinton's Opera House reception, will you publish: one, the suggested guest list
as prepared by the Office of the Status of Women; two, the guest list as amended by Mrs Howard or her staff; and, three, the final list of attendees?
—This will really create jobs.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —Yes, what a big issue. As I have just said, three‐quarters of a million Australians are out of work as a result of Labor. Perhaps we are starting to understand why. Instead of coming in here and talking about inflation, interest rates, all those other business incentives, small business, what is happening in the regions, et cetera, all Senator Crowley can concern herself with is the guest list for the reception for Mrs Clinton.

answer.para:
It is a clear reflection of Labor's priorities. It demonstrates again the disarray that Labor is in, as was recorded in the
Age
. I referred to that article in relation to Senator Carr and his factional brawls. Senator Carr, I do not know whether you have won, but it is good to welcome you back to the Senate.

If you concentrated less on your internal difficulties and a little bit more on the role that you are to play as a major political party in the future, you will start directing yourself to the big issues, Senator Crowley. I regret that you have not done so. But, if you really want a guest list, I will make inquiries and see what can be made available.

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is interesting how loud you protest, Senator Hill. Why are you so touchy on it? Is it because you have read Alan Ramsay in the
Sydney Morning Herald
? You promised to be different and you are worse than before. Minister, do you think it appropriate that the first lady, Mrs Hillary Clinton, was forced to ask her staff to smuggle in through a service corridor those people she wished to meet?

—I notice that there was a judge of the Federal Court, Cathy Branson, on the list. I do not think anyone was smuggled in through the side door, Senator Crowley. I would worry less about that and more about some of the big national issues and then the Labor Party will be taking the first step towards becoming relevant again. Practise
being a good opposition, start to develop some alternative policies and then one day in the future, while you may not be forgiven for the debacles of the past, you will at least get another chance. You will not get it when you worry about petty matters, Senator. All I can say is that I am pleased that you were here to debate the appropriation bills on Thursday rather than attending receptions.

question.block.title: Trade with the United States of America

talk.start.para: —My question is about the speech by Mr Clinton to the Senate and the House of Representatives. Mr Clinton referred to efforts being made by his government to extend the reach of free and fair trade. He also said—almost in the same breath—that they would be pursuing intellectual property rights. Is that not really saying to us, `We will sell you our diseases and you will buy our knowledge'? Is it not a fact that neither the articles of confederation when the United States confederated nor the constitution enable the sale of diseased products across borders—
—Order! The time for asking the question has expired. I do not think you have identified to whom it was directed.
—Sorry, it is to the Leader of the Government.

—I knew it was for me, but I was waiting for the question. If, from what I understand, you are suggesting that in some ways intellectual property should be given away, unfortunately intellectual property is built upon capital and there has to be some inducement for the investment of that capital. It is important to give protection to that investment in order that it might continue to flow. The outcome of that is that, through various ways, the whole international—
—Stick to the brief.
—I haven't got a brief. The whole international community therefore benefits from the capital that has been invested. If the question is what I think it is, I respectfully disagree with you.

—I ask the minister whether, in respect of that matter, the amount of money that will be going from us to the
United States far outweighs that coming in reverse. More particularly, how come the United States is trying to get us to accept its diseased fish, its diseased salmon, which is going to cruelly affect the salmon industry in my state, when in fact, under its constitution and under the original articles of confederation, its states are enabled to refuse products which are diseased?

—That is not the question I was expecting. If we are talking about the proposed salmon imports, I thought they were from Canada and not the United States. I am having a lot of trouble relating that to intellectual property. What I can assure you of is that we have no intention of importing diseased fish. That is why we have AQIS in place—to protect our interests, both in terms of our health and our environment.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Why did Mr Moore on 23 July this year and again last Thursday issue press releases claiming actual examples of syndicate arrangements used to generate generous tax benefits when the examples cited were constructs and not actual cases? When did the minister learn that they were not real examples and when did he take the opportunity to correct the public record?

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —I remind Senator Cook—he would know, as he was minister—that, in relation to the examples given by Minister Moore, the government is legally constrained by section 45(7) of the IR&D Act and also, I understand, under the taxation act from providing specific details of cases where that information would enable those particular companies to be actually identified.
—We know that bit but what we want now is the answer to the question.
—You want the names, Senator?
—We don't want any names. We want facts, not fiction.

—I am delighted with Senator Crowley's intervention. As she said,
she didn't want the names; she wanted the facts. We have given the facts. Minister Moore gave four examples, when in fact there are something like 140 that could be given, of rorting of the system under the syndicated R&D.

answer.para: Senator Cook is drawing an extraordinarily long bow, and he knows it. Senator Cook attended the 25 September estimates committee hearing and, I might say, interrogated at great length. I understand why Senator Cook went through the interrogation: he had been minister and he did not want some sort of a slur being cast on his own character. I do not blame him for that. This was as a result of the questions being pursued by Senator Cook. I do not think he doubted that these cases were good examples.

talk.start.para: —They are not.

—Here is Senator Cook saying that they are not. Back on 25 September Senator Cook accepted the fact that this occurred. The line of his questioning at the time was: did this occur after or before the innovation statement and as a result—

—They did not accept it, Warwick. Go back to
Hansard
.
—I'll quote it for you, Senator Cook, if you like. It was pointed out to Senator Cook by the departmental representative, Mr Evans:

answer.para: I think I can best characterise them as representational of what was and is occurring within the operation of syndication.
Senator Cook went on to say:
So representational means that these are not actual cases—
Mr Evans said:
There are some features which were changed—

This was on 25 September. We have a beat-up now, after the last couple of days, as if there has been a sudden discovery. No-one walked away from this. No-one has said otherwise. We did not quote company XYZ or company ABC. These are features which were changed to protect the confidentiality of the syndicate.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish. You called them real cases.

—It is wonderful to get Senator Bob Collins' intervention. When things get a bit quiet, you can rely on Senator Bob Collins to come in with a marvellous interjection that gives me an opportunity to talk about one of the examples. In example 1—this is what the minister was referring to—a researcher sold core technology to a private researcher for $1,000. Three days later, the same private researcher sold the same core technology to a syndicate for $14 million, ripping off the taxpayer. Certainly, some of those numbers were not exact because the exact numbers would have identified the recipients. Senator Cook knows that. Mr Crean should know it.

answer.para: How can the opposition come in here and defend people who were rorting the system, the ordinary battlers in Australia, in this instance to the tune of a $21 million tax deduction? Does it really matter whether the private researcher paid $500, $1,000 or $2,000? Would the senator justify it if it were $100,000? Yet the rort was in the order of $21 million. I make the point that it was not illegal, but it was a rort.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I have here a copy of the actual press release. I have asked an attendant to give it to you, minister. I also make the point that none of the industry who gave evidence all day Friday recognised any of those cases or said that any of those cases would have been approved. Why, as late as last Friday, was a spokesman of Mr Moore's office saying that `it was made clear that these were examples of the types of cases' in the first press release? Now you have a copy of the press release can you point out exactly where in the first press release this was made clear?

—Senator Cook knows this as well as anyone, but he is trying to draw a long bow on this: four examples were given. There were in excess of 140 samples of syndicated R&D not being used for the purpose of R&D. As I said, I can understand the sensitivity of Senator Cook on this because he himself was responsible for this. He knew about the fact that it was being rorted. He mentioned in the Senate estimates commit
tee that he intended to do something about it and was somewhat surprised to find that when we got into government the advice given to us was: if you are going to get rid of these rorts you have to get rid of the syndicated R&D. That is exactly what we did. Senator Cook asks, `What is the position?' He was questioned at great length.
(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Given today's release of good news on new capital expenditure data which endorses the budget forecast for growth and investment, what message does this send to the opposition who continue to talk down the Australian economy? Are these figures yet again an indication that the Howard government's approach to economic management, low inflation and low interest rates is working?

answer.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Chapman, for that question. There are three things which are quite predictable—death, taxes and the opposition trying to talk down the economy. That is what generally happens. The data which was released today was very good news for all Australians, except the opposition and the shadow Treasurer. To quote the ABS, expectations for the remainder of the 1996-97 financial year remain strong. We expect new capital expenditure of $42.9 billion at current prices, a revision upwards of 7.8 per cent from the estimate and 19.2 per cent higher than the corresponding estimate for the 1995-96 financial year.

answer.para: Investment expectations have now risen by about 37 per cent between the first estimate in December last year and the latest estimate. The budget estimate forecast business investment growth of 14 per cent in 1996-97 and today's figures show that that forecast is right on track.

talk.start.para: —So unemployment is still going up.

—Right on track, Senator Conroy. Our GDP forecast is also looking good. Business investment growth is a key component of the forecast for the economy overall because investment is expected to
contribute around one half of the overall growth of the economy.
—What are your projections for employment over the next three years? How many jobs are there?

—Senator Conroy, you are speaking about employment. You come from a party that had 13 years. I am not holding you personally responsible because you only arrived late on the moment but you had 13 years to get it right and you delivered the worst recession in 60 years. The Labor Party are the last people who should be talking about unemployment. The problem is, Senator Conroy, you have just demonstrated the proposition I put at the start—that is, the Labor Party will do anything to talk the economy down.

answer.para: The figures released today are unambiguously good news for the economy. The shadow Treasurer said that the capital import figures would mean bad investment figures for plant and equipment. Remember that the shadow Treasurer said that just a short time ago? How wrong was he? Investment in equipment, plant and machinery grew by 2.4 per cent over the quarter on top of growth of 13.3 per cent in the June quarter and is now 21 per cent higher than this time last year.
Today's figures are exceedingly good news. They add to the other good news figures that have come out on the economy in recent weeks. Underlying inflation is at its lowest level for two decades.

talk.start.para: —That's because you are killing the economy.

—Senator Conroy says that we killed the economy, but the investment figures which came out today were exceedingly good. Make up your mind, Senator Conroy. You should listen to the answer. If you listened to the answer you would not make such a silly mistake, Senator Conroy. Home interest rates, as everyone knows, have fallen and are falling. They have fallen one and three-quarter percentage points since the election. The budget forecast of two per cent employment growth is right on track and business investment is set to achieve 14 per cent growth. What we have here is good news
for the economy. We have a Labor Party which cannot get its lines right. We have good news and they are still saying that we have deadened the economy.
(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Australian government refused to resettle any mainland dissidents now living in Hong Kong ahead of next year's Chinese take over? Given that Australia was willing to grant residency to more than 20,000 Chinese students after the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident, why is the Australian government being so inflexible on this matter? Is it not a fact that the Canadian foreign minister has offered asylum to some of these activists?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —This presumably came out of recent press reports. I remind you that since 1989—
—Have you any advice at all?

—I have some advice here from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I thought you might like to know the content of it. You know that Australia has taken a number of Chinese resettlement cases, some through Hong Kong. You know that we have a long history of receiving resettlement cases from all over the world, including the Asian region. Since 1975 we have resettled some 10,000 Indo-Chinese refugees from Hong Kong.

answer.para: Since 1989 Australia has granted permanent residence to some 20,000 Chinese nationals in Australia, as well as 8,000 family members who have subsequently joined them in this country. The background is that Australia has a very proud record in this area. That does not specifically answer the question that you have asked, Senator, so I will take that back to the foreign minister and see whether I can get some further information.

talk.start.para:
—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is the minister aware that Australia has led the way on trade liberali
sation in terms of eliminating tariffs, non‐tariff barriers and industry and trade assistance schemes? Is the minister aware that this has placed many Australian firms at a severe disadvantage relative to their major overseas competitors? Is the minister aware that, while their competitors can readily sell final goods in Australia, our firms do not have the same access to many foreign markets, especially for value added products? I ask the minister: in the APEC negotiations, will the government commit Australia to a trading regime which, on balance, leaves Australian firms no worse off in terms of tariffs and other support measures relative to their competitors in the APEC region?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —Madam President, as you know, our policies of trade liberalisation are designed in our national interest. I thought the Prime Minister put it quite well yesterday in Manila when he was asked a similar question: `What are the tangible benefits for maintaining this push for trade liberalisation of the Australian economy?' His answer was, `More jobs, higher rates of economic growth and the prospect that greater trade flows in the region will provide new jobs for Australians.' That is ultimately what the goal of economic policy is all about—generating greater economic growth. More jobs for Australians must always be the test of any Australian Prime Minister in applying, in effect, the theory to the practical circumstances.

answer.para: So we have taken the decision—which was also the decision of the previous government—that to press for further trade liberalisation will encourage growth and provide greater job opportunities for Australians. There has been some debate as to who is out in front in this liberalisation. These situations are quite difficult to equate at times because, in some parts of the policy mix, Australia might be out in front; in other parts—certainly in relation to agricultural policies—we have been out in front on trade liberalisation for very long period of time. We have engaged in a policy process that is finally starting to open up those who have protected their rural industries to the disadvantage of our efficient producers.

break.para: In some other instances, of course, countries have pointed to areas in which they have had low tariff or other protection regimes and they have argued that we have been higher. That debate continues. It is interesting that, in fact, if we go back to exactly what the Osaka agenda states, it says that each economy would endeavour to ensure that its liberalisations were comparable. That is what we are seeking to do, although, as I said, it is sometimes difficult to compare. The important thing is that, out of this process of general liberalisation, we all should gain through greater economic growth, particularly job opportunities for Australians.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Minister, if Australian firms and farmers remain disadvantaged and if other APEC nations are seen not to have delivered reciprocal trade liberalisation concessions, will the government consider using, or at least threatening to use, retaliatory measures, and, if so, what?

—That is not the way we are going. What we are doing is using our liberalisation to argue for better access for our business community in the region. There are some very well‐known examples in which we are seeking to do that. Whilst I say at times it is difficult to compare the various trade regimes, nevertheless, within the charter of the Osaka agenda, we believe that liberalisation, if it is comparable, gives us a legitimacy in arguing that, from the basis of our liberalisation, we should expect liberalisation in those areas, particularly within our region, where there are still considerable obstacles to entry by Australian firms. As a South Australian, I make particular mention of the car industry. We would very much wish to see greater access for Australian car producers within the region and we are doing everything possible to achieve that goal.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, you would recall launching the national code of practice for recreational and sport fishing at Stradbroke Island in August this year. In congratulating Recfish on

—My question is directed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I understand that the changes to HECS announced in the budget will create a fairer system, one which acknowledges the clear private benefits that higher education brings to the individual. Why then is the opposition opposed to changes which will make the system more equitable? Could the minister inform the Senate of the government's view of changes to the scheme?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I would ask you to address yourself to the first part of the question. The second part was certainly in order, but the first part of the question asking for an opinion on the opposition's view was not in order at all.
—The former part of the question I would regard as not being in order, but the latter certainly is. Senator Vanstone may deal with that.

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —This government does want to introduce a greater degree of equity into the higher education system. It wants to do that in a number of ways—for example, by changing the HECS contribution that students make, by shifting it to a differentiated level, and by some other changes as well. It is interesting to note what those people who profess not to be in favour of these changes have to say or, more importantly, what they do not have to say about these sorts of changes. What they do not have to say is perhaps an indicator of their motives.

answer.para:
I have never heard these people justify why it is that a doctor and a lawyer should pay the same annual contribution for their university studies as nurses and teachers. I have never heard the people opposed to these changes make that justification. I have never heard the people opposing these changes indicate that other taxpayers give about $18,000 a year to educate a medical student. I have never heard people opposing these changes make that
point. The taxpayers, of course, who give that $18,000 include the battlers, the PAYE taxpayers.

The people opposing these changes equally do not make it clear that the medical student, when she or he finally becomes a doctor, will pay, under the changes, only about $5,500, or 30 per cent, of the cost for that year. That is the only contribution that will be sought. I do not hear these people say that this contribution is, in effect, a real interest free loan for those taxpayers who receive the opportunity, as opposed to the other taxpayers who do not get that opportunity, because it is only indexed to the inflation rate.

I also do not hear them say that this contribution is not pay as you learn but pay as you earn. They say quite the opposite. I hear people opposed to these changes trying to frighten students off suggesting that they will have to pay up front. I never hear these people talk about the very real and substantial benefits that go to graduates—that is, lower unemployment rates and higher incomes—for the rest of their lives.

Those people who oppose shifting the point at which HECS will have to be repaid from $28,000 down to about $21,000 never actually say to you that not only do they think it is fair that the 25 per cent of school leavers who go to university get, at a minimum, about $20,000 worth of higher education but also that they think they should not have to pay their contribution back until they are earning more than 56 per cent of the rest of the population. That is what people who oppose these changes think is equitable.

I never hear them saying that, in the years of free education, the rise in the participation rate from socially disadvantaged groups was something other than substantial. It was, in fact, negligible. Some figures would indicate that it was negative. In 1980, for example, 59 per cent of children from professional parents went to higher education. By 1989, this had risen to 69 per cent. So that tells you who is getting the benefit out of highly subsidised education—the sorts of people that members opposite have sought to protect and look after, their own constituency, rather than taking any
consideration for the funds that battlers, through their tax paying contribution, put into this.

I am sure that Senator Sandy Macdonald would, if there was time, be interested in the views of former Senator Walsh on this matter. If he cares to ask a supplementary question on that, I would be happy to provide him with that information. It is important to bear in mind—
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would be interested in hearing the views of former Senator Walsh on the funding of higher education.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think we can say that you were sucked in, Senator Macdonald. I take a serious point of order. On previous rulings you have given in relation to supplementary questions, a supplementary question invited by the minister in that form, not a supplementary question to the answer she was giving, on the precedent of your own rulings, is out of order.
—It seemed to me that this was a supplementary question that arose from the answer whether the minister invited it or not.

answer.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
answer.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talk.start.para: —I was trying to give an indication of the equity issues involved here and would have gone on to point out that the participation rates of children of skilled parents during those years in fact fell—that is, the participation of children of professional parents rose and that of skilled parents fell. This is what former Senator Walsh had to say:

answer.para: Free universities fully funded by the Commonwealth were, like many problems which plagued Budgets through the 1980s, a product of the Whitlam Government. By 1985, published analyses had shown there was no change in the socio economic background of university students following the abolition of fees in 1974. Students still came overwhelmingly from rich families. The change which the abolition of fees was supposed to sponsor had not happened.
This is the crucial bit:

Heavily subsidised university education was probably regressive; free university education was
more regressive. It was, predictably, a sacred cow for the bourgeois lefties who were its beneficiaries.

para.emphasis: (Time expired)

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —There are a number of questions there. I was just musing as I listened to Senator Faulkner that I met a member of the Women in Medicine Committee of the AMA the other day at the reception for Mrs Clinton. The issue was not raised with me there.
—Oh!
—There was plenty of opportunity. You don't like me mentioning it, do you, you whingers?

answer.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!
—They do not like to hear these things. I know that somewhere here in a briefing note from the minister for health I do have some information about misinformation that has been put about.

But I will certainly investigate that aspect for you, as I would be concerned if that were to be the case. I do not believe it to be true but, as minister responsible for assisting the Prime Minister on the status of women, I am happy to look into that matter in more detail for you.

I find quite extraordinary the amount of misinformation that is going around about this. We are hearing all sorts of stories about whether people are going to be able to service any particular state or whether they are going to be able to get training. Yet isn't it a strange thing, Madam President, that we have young graduates who are complaining that they should receive extra training before they get a provider number? It does not matter to me too much whether they are women or whether they are men or whether they are in a part-time situation or whether they are in a full time situation. The patient's interests surely are paramount. I would fight to the death to see that the patients get quality medical care.

talk.start.para: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Would you accept, Minister, that perhaps the reason that the representative of the Women in Medicine Committee that you met at Hillary Clinton's reception at the Opera House did not raise this issue with you is that no-one, apart from members of the Liberal Party or their friends, got through the front door? Or did you meet her in the service corridor? Thirdly, I ask the minister: would you concede that these arrangements will reduce the level of choice for women wishing to arrange their lives, flexibly secure in the knowledge that one day they can return to full‐time or part-time practice?

question.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para:
—On 6 November last Senator Mackay asked me a question in my capacity representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I seek leave to incorporate the response in
Hansard
.

question.para: Leave granted.

para.emphasis: The answer read as follows—

break.para: I am advised that in response to a previous question by Senator Faulkner in the Estimates Committee, on the impact of Budget changes on holders of a Commonwealth Seniors Health Card, a departmental official had explained to the Senator that an estimated 800 people would now not be eligible.

The answer provided to Senator Faulkner's written question showed that there were no savings taken from the overall appropriation for hearing services as a result of the eligibility change for holders of the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card and said explicitly that the savings `are expected to be minimal' and `the appropriation has not been reduced'.

While the government did reduce the overall appropriation for hearing services, it did not take away the amount expected to be saved from the change to eligibility of holders of the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card, which is less than $500,000, and allowed this to remain in the appropriation to be used for hearing services.

Senator Newman responded to the hearing services issue in a more general way, focusing not only on the impact on Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders, but pointing out that our broad savings measures were driven by the debt left to this nation by the previous government and that hearing services `was one area' where some savings would need to be made.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray asked me a question on 21 November 1996. I would now like to provide additional information regarding Australia's APEC individual action plan. As to Australia's individual action plan submitted to APEC, the government has committed itself in respect of foreign investment to retain only specified restrictions in relation to foreign investment in sensitive sectors, including media, telecommunications and civil aviation, rationalised restrictions on foreign investment and real estate by mid-1997 involving some overall liberalisation, a review by mid‐1997 and a screening system in relation to foreign investment in the non-sensitive sectors. This would possibly include increasing the notification thresholds to save $50 million and/or limiting the criteria for rejection using the contrary to national interest test to considerations relating to the national security, public order, environment protection and heritage issues.

para.break: On the issue of the liberalisation of real estate policy, the operative word in the IAP commitment is to `rationalise' foreign invest ment policy in respect of real estate. This has become complex and requires rationalisation. Whilst rationalisation is likely to involve some overall liberalisation, this would be quite limited. Importantly, the general prohibition on the purchase by foreign interests of existing developed residential real estate, houses, flats, et cetera, will be maintained. Further, the development requirement in respect of purchases of vacant land by foreign interests—namely the commencement of continuous development within 12 months of the date of purchase—will also be maintained.

speech.speaker: Cook, Sen Peter

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the proposed abolition of the syndicated research and development program.

In question time today, Senator Parer answered, in a most unsatisfactory way, a question that I put to him. We know that this government used the example of the Wright family, a fictitious family created in order to pretend that abuse of social security was occurring when, in the example provided, there was no abuse of social security. The government came into this chamber and admitted that the example they were holding out to be true was indeed false. That is now a well‐known fact on the public record.

Today, and indeed last Friday, we have learnt that the government has been at it again—falsifying the facts, fabricating the evidence. It provided a press statement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) on 23 July and again last Thursday alleging that that there were four examples of actual case studies in which syndication under research and development provisions had been abused. They attached those four case studies to their press release on 23 July. They re‐issued that press release unamended last Thursday when they launched their START program. They have used those case studies as justification for terminating the syndication R&D program.

break.para: This is not a light matter. This is a matter that has caused a storm of outrage in Australian industry. This has caused a storm of protest by reputable Australian companies that their reputations are being slurred by the government's continually exhibiting these case examples and pretending that there are widespread rorts in this system. The government did two misleading things. It said that it based its findings and its press report on a BIE report. There is no such BIE report. The report that it refers to is a report of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism. It also said that it based its decision to terminate R&D on the four case examples. What did the press release actually say? The heading in the ministers' press release was `Use of R&D syndication to generate tax benefits—actual case examples' and there were four of them. What we now know from evidence given to the Senate economics committee inquiry which sat on Friday is that these are not true. These examples are fabrications. These examples do not represent, as the heading on this press release says, actual case examples. Here, again, the government is caught red‐handed, fabricating the evidence to justify its decision.

You do not just have my word for that. On Friday, we had evidence from a whole host of industry sources who said three key things about these case examples. These industry sources represented 90 per cent overall of all of the applications for syndicated R&D. What were the three things that they said? They said that they did not recognise any of the four examples as being typical or true. They said that those examples are not typical of the applications that they have made under this scheme. And, importantly for this debate, they said that none of those examples would have got through the guidelines as they had been tightened by the former government in December last year in the innovations statement.

para.break: So the examples, if they had been applications, would have got knocked out under the guidelines last year. These cannot be examples that are true today and these cannot be examples from which the government can pretend that there is a justification for cancel ling syndicated R&D. The government has been caught red‐handed, fabricating the evidence, pretending on the basis of that fabrication that it can do things.

break.para:
The government has not apologised to the Senate. It has not corrected the record. None of the ministers have come out publicly and re‐organised what they have said so as to reflect the true case. While they persist in pretending that this is the true case, the public are being misled, and misled in an important way because this touches on the ability of the Australian economy to grow rapidly, to create jobs in the area of research and development and to put Australia in the leadership of product development in the world so that we can win markets and create more jobs with the exports of those products. Industry almost to a person on Friday gave evidence that the government is wrong. It is about time that the government corrected the record.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I respond briefly to Senator Cook. Senator Cook is trying to draw a long bow and establish some sort of relationship between this and other cases that were quoted in this place, but I think Senator Cook has to ask himself the question: who is he defending? Why is he defending rorts that were apparent in the R&D syndication?
—I am not.
—Yes, you are.
—I am not.
—Why are you saying that rorting was not going on? Is that what you are saying—that it was not going on?
—I never said that. I said that you have lied. That is what I said. Tell the truth!
—Thank you, Senator Cook. I am glad that Senator Cook has interjected to say—
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that comment.
—He did not say anything rude, did he?
—I said that you had lied and I think that is unparliamentary. I am not allowed to say that so I will withdraw it.

—Senator Cook's generosity is overtaken only by his good looks, I might say. I think this, Senator Cook, points out that industry did not recognise any of these particular cases. That is quite right. This was pointed out to him not on Friday but over two months ago. I think it was two months ago—5 September, anyway—in the estimates committee.

break.para: There was a whole series, and I might say that Senator Cook did a stirling job of pursuing this with great vigour. But the point was made by Mr Evans of the department over and over again that the cases did represent actual cases. Mr Evans said, `They are characterised as representing what was and what is occurring within the operation of a syndication system.' I repeat: what is occurring.

We came into government. We were advised of these particular rorts that were going on. I might make the point clear—and I think Senator Cook will agree with me—that during the estimates committee it was pointed out that, while the term `rorting' was used, it was not illegal, it was quite legal. Senator Cook pursued the departmental officials at great length by asking them, `Did this occur before or after the innovation statement?' I think he made the point in the little burst he gave a few minutes ago of saying that the industry people pointed out that none of this would have got through the guidelines.

That was not the evidence given by Mr Evans at the Senate estimates committee. Mr Evans pointed out that, while he was under the impression—and I have not got the exact words in front of me, although I do have the transcript here—that they would not have got through the guidelines, in retrospect he felt they would. I think Senator Cook will remember that exchange between Mr Evans and him.

para.break: With regard to the evidence given last Friday, of which I have only seen some transcripts—I have not seen the full transcript—I think it is worth mentioning that Senator Ferguson, as chairman of the committee, asked Mr Dillon, `Are the examples provided in the joint release of 23 July con sistent with actual syndicates that were registered?' Mr Dillon replied, `The answer to that, Senator, is yes.' So the point being made was that these were—

talk.start.para: —Quote further.
—Quote further; thank you, Senator. Senator Ferguson said yes. Mr Dillon then said, `I know it is inconsistent with the advice provided to the committee this morning but the answer is yes.'
—He also said that there is no such exact case.

—The thing that we are looking at is that, with the best of intent, Senator, a system was introduced. I have no problems, and I do not think anyone has any particular problems, with encouraging R&D. It is important for any country. R&D is vital to the development of most industries. But what we saw on coming to government were two problems: one was that the R&D syndication was being rorted, and the other was gravedigging.

break.para: Anyone, I think, in this place who has any connection with business will know that gravedigging was going on—and that is going back in time. I know of companies, in fact, that have not paid a franked dividend for the past four or five years because of the gravedigging exercise. Was that the original intent of R&D? Senator, I would have to say that the answer to that would have to be no.

speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —I too wish to take note of Senator Parer's answer to Senator Cook's question—and I was somewhat incredulous at the answer, I am afraid. I was present at the estimates committee where I listened to Senator Cook's detailed, measured, persistent and careful questioning of the minister and department on this issue. I conducted my own questioning. I was interested in establishing just what validity there was for two things: firstly, the aspect of rorting, especially after the tightening of the system in December 1995 and January 1996; and, secondly, whether syndication should be dumped because it was ineffective.

speech.para:
On the first question, Minister Parer began the estimates by using what I refer to as the
`demon‐speak' of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) —a method of demonising things he does not like—such as rorting. By the end—and the instant will be recalled, and I will paraphrase it—Minister Parer was saying that rorting was not perhaps the appropriate way of talking about this matter. Today I heard Minister Parer back onto the marketing or propaganda line of knocking it over.

I have no quarrel with the belief that syndication might not be an effective or appropriate system. But to keep using the demonising language of rorting, I think, weakens the government's argument. Let me say quite clearly—and I have no ministerial record to protect, and I say this as an independent, objective person, I hope—that to me there has been no empirical objective or even circumstantial evidence on the record, in the budget debates, the estimates or the inquiry that has proven that rorting, which means scams, corruption, illegality, for those who got through a tight screening process, has gone on. Certainly, there were shonky people who tried to get up, but they did not get through the screening process—and that was acknowledged by the department.

As such, the use of the word `rorting' is a clear slur, until proven, on the three firms that constitute 90 per cent of the approved syndication systems. I think, if I may say so, Mr Deputy President, that is an unattractive and unhappy way for the government to pursue their agenda, which is one of saving money by reducing these programs to cut the deficit. If that is your aim, that is clearly understood. But do not do it by casting aspersions upon those who have conducted their programs in a legal manner and who have not been proven—by the Treasury, the ministers or extensive inquiries—to have rorted or corrupted the system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

question.speaker: Abetz, Sen Eric

talk.start.para: —I move:

question.para:
That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferris today, relating to the railway
industry and the proposed privatisation of Australian National.

The subsidy paid per employee, above and beyond the salary that they earn, is $30,000 per annum. That is the state in which the rail system was left when we took over government. I am pleased to say that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) immediately took it upon himself to deal with that problem. He commissioned the Brew report. As it now turns out, the Brew report was quite conservative in relation to the estimated loss that AN would accrue during this year. AN announced the particular figure that it anticipated; Brew suggested another figure, which was higher. The real result is higher than both figures.

talk.start.para: —What were the figures?

answer.speaker: Abetz, Sen Eric

talk.start.para: —We are now expecting a $250 million blow‐out, Senator Sherry. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate does not know those fundamental facts, yet undoubtedly he was part of the brainstorming session that occurred when the opposition decided to ask questions about Mrs Clinton's visit.

answer.para:
Mr Deputy President, it really does indicate how the Labor Party have allowed their eyes to fall from the main game, doesn't it? They are no longer focused on the real issues. They are snapping around the heels of government about invitation lists while we are getting on with the real business of government in this country—restructuring the rail system to
provide real job security for those that are employed in the rail industry.

Talking about job opportunities, it is very interesting that when Labor first came to power AN had in excess of 9,000 employees. When we took over the number had fallen to well below 3,000, so the ALP should not try to hector us about how we ought to look after the few remaining employees of AN. We will be looking after them. speech.para: That the matter specified in paragraph (1) be referred to the Select Committee on Superannuation for inquiry and report by the first sitting day in March 1997.

(1)
The appropriateness of current unfunded defined benefit superannuation schemes' application to judges and parliamentarians, including but not limited to:

para.tab:
(a)
the equity between members;

(f)
the appropriateness of replacing such schemes with a fully-funded accumulation scheme;

(g)

(h)
the capacity for making superannuation arrangements less complex than current arrangements; and

(i)
the administrative costs of such arrangements and their alternatives.

speech.para:
(2)
That for the purposes of the inquiry the committee take evidence from the public, Government agencies and State, Territory and federal government departments, and conduct public hearings as appropriate.

This matter has been on the
Notice Paper
to and fro for some time. My terms of reference seek to investigate the current superannuation scheme for judges and parliamentarians. The terms of reference show that we seek to look at the fairness of the schemes, particularly in relation to the cost to the public purse and in relation to benefits received by other citizens.

The Democrats recognise that there is a need to achieve a fine balance here. There is a need to have an appropriate superannuation scheme that is essential to ensure that parliamentarians are adequately compensated for the resulting vagaries and insecurities of life
on being elected to parliament. But I think it is true that so many things have changed. We assumed that members of parliament would stay in parliament as long as possible and the focus was on retirement income.

What is happening now is that the superannuation scheme we have in place actually fails the test of fairness. When politicians are able to retire in their 40s and early 50s with benefits worth $1 million to $2 million, with 80 per cent of the cost having been borne not by the employee's contributions but by the Commonwealth, I think that does require us to look and ask in 1996 and in relation to other citizens if this can be judged fair.

Preservation rules are now very tight for other sectors of the work force. Few people can now access their superannuation before age 55. Few workers born after 1960 will be able to access their superannuation before aged 60. But we are different. Federal politicians can do both those things. It is not just that: federal politicians can line up for other government jobs and, even though pension payments might be suspended while they hold that job, they can still line up for other benefits later.

According to the Department of Finance, the parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme involves a cost to the Commonwealth equivalent to 78 per cent of parliamentarians' salaries. The way the scheme is designed does benefit longer term parliamentarians while providing significant inequities for shorter term parliamentarians.

With politicians running for office at earlier ages, which I welcome, and retiring earlier—I think that is something to be encouraged too; I think a healthy turnover of politicians is something we should pay attention to—the scheme is becoming less about retirement income and more about providing some kind of nest egg for a second career. That is where I think the big changes have happened in the career of parliamentarians and that is why I think it is appropriate now to ask whether this emphasis, this focus, is now appropriate.

The National Commission of Audit, a great deal of whose report I vehemently disagree with, has made several recommendations about the parliamentarians' scheme. It has
recommended that benefits should be paid through accumulation benefits arrangements and that the amount of superannuation should be determined by the individual member as part of overall remuneration entitlements. Whether you agree with that or not, we are not seeking to pre-empt. We are simply saying that there is an element of transparency attractive in those recommendations. That is why we have incorporated those into the terms of reference. The terms of reference also cover federal judges' superannuation. This raises similar issues to those of the federal politicians' scheme. The National Commission of Audit made similar recommendations about this as well.

Despite the entreaties of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), the final terms of reference that I am asking us to vote on do not include the Public Service superannuation scheme. I have thought about this at length and I do not agree that the Public Service should be included at this stage. There are two main reasons for this. The first reason is that I do not trust conservative governments with Public Service superannuation. We can look at various state examples, and I will come to that in a moment. I think it is much more appropriate that the issue of superannuation be looked at in the next enterprise bargaining round, not by a federal government seeking a pre-emptive strike. I think that is what they are up to. My second reason is that I think it is very inappropriate to seek to do this now in the context of a larger scale public sector reform move, evident in the discussion paper released today by Minister Reith.

I remind the coalition of their election policy promises. The coalition, in its Public Service policy, promised to guarantee—you could not get a stronger word than that—all accrued superannuation entitlements and retain separate arrangements for public sector superannuation. This same promise was repeated in their superannuation policy.

If you look at history, you can see that conservative state governments in election campaigns made the same promises. But in government, in an effort to make a few bucks, to reduce the deficit, most moved to cut
public sector superannuation entitlements down from the level guaranteed in current legislation to the minimum level set by the superannuation guarantee charge. In each state, on each occasion, the argument given was, `Well, goodness, we can't have these terrible, terrible unfunded liabilities of superannuation schemes.'

I was on the Senate select committee some years ago and we looked at the unfunded liabilities issue. The conclusion of the committee was that this is not a major crisis. I would argue that there has been no argument sustained to cut entitlements based on the scare tactic of `we have got this major crisis at hand'. We don't. The government actuary regularly reports on the liabilities under the government's superannuation scheme and has reported a steadily declining proportion of GDP in liabilities. Indeed, the most recent report showed that accruing costs were less than emerging costs, suggesting that future generations of taxpayers might be worse off if we move to a fully funded scheme. The National Commission of Audit even conceded that this was an on balance decision. The commission also recommended that, in moving to a fully funded accumulation rather than an unfunded defined benefits scheme, the total value of remuneration packages not be reduced by the change.

I suspect that only the first part of the commission's recommendations are acceptable to the government because, like Mr Nick Greiner did and like Premiers Kennett, Brown, and Richard Court have already done, I believe that this federal government would, if it had the chance, reduce Public Service superannuation entitlements to the minimum set by the superannuation guarantee charge. Indeed, that was clear to me in the first draft of the terms of reference that Finance Minister Fahey sent me as an alternative to the ones I was proposing.

The Commission of Audit did not actually do the government's bidding in this area. You might be able to argue that it certainly took up the ideological arguments elsewhere, but in the area of Public Service superannuation it did not do the government's bidding. It recommended no reduction in benefits and it
saw no problem with the unfunded liabilities issue. I referred to that a minute ago.

Not being able to embrace the recommendations of the Commission of Audit, the government thought, `Here is a go. We might be able to tack this on to Senator Kernot's terms of reference on politicians' superannuation.' I have thought about it at length—obviously this has been on the
Notice Paper
