Here is the government going halfway to the Hanson dictum. Here is the government discriminating against people and creating a cop‐out for itself by rearranging immigration
policy by disincentive. It is saying to people whom it does not want in this country, `Don't come here because we are not going to afford you the same benefits everybody else in Australia gets until after you have been here for 24 months. The most difficult period you will ever face in this country is the period when we are going to make it hardest for you.'

This is the backdoor way of cutting the number of immigrants coming to this country by the 12,000 or 14,000 that the government is preparing to cut this year. But it is also a backdoor way of saying to those who are going to find it hardest when they come to this country because their first language, for example, is not English, `We are going to make it particularly hard for you because the social security net is going to be pulled away from you.' It is immigration redesigned by stealth. It is something that this Senate should be opposing.

I gather that the Labor Party is not going to oppose this legislation. I am pleased to hear that the Democrats will oppose this legislation. The Greens will be opposing this legislation because it is wrong legislation. It is not good enough to simply change the strictures on people arriving in this country which currently pertain. Whereas at present they wait six months before they get social security benefits, they will have to wait 24 months—which is what the ALP is supporting. That is drifting in the wrong direction as well, when we should be holding the line.

I am indebted to Jo De Silva in my office for her work in contacting a number of groups concerned with social welfare, immigration and ethnic affairs in this country. There is widespread concern about this legislation. There is widespread concern throughout the community, which is interested in social justice—and isn't that a fair go?—that this legislation cuts right across that national ethos.

We will oppose the second reading of this bill. It should not get through this place. It should, like the regulations brought in here a couple of weeks ago, be stopped in its tracks. However, the numbers appear to be for it and it therefore comes down to juggling with
proposed amendments—and there are a lot of them—to try to blunt the worst effects of this legislation for people coming to this country.

Therefore, we will support those amendments which limit the range of people that this legislation cheats of rightful social security benefits as permanent residents in this country. For example, we will oppose the 104‐week—that is, two‐year—waiting period for spouses and partners of people who are already receiving social security benefits. It means that those couples are going to be living on half benefits in this country, as the one social security beneficiary will have to share her or his income with the partner.

We will also support amendments to remove any reference to that narrow entitlement to special benefit—the bottom of the pit, where people who cannot get any other benefit at all are placed. The vote of the Greens on this legislation will be trying to draw some of its teeth. The legislation's mouth should not be open. Its bite should not be upon those people who have gained legitimate entry to this country. The government should be ashamed of bringing this legislation into parliament. But there it is. With Senator Stott Despoja, I appeal to the Labor Party to think again about giving this legislation passage. We should be voting against it.

speech.speaker: Woodley, Sen John

talk.start.para: —I, too, rise to speak on this appalling proposition that is before the Senate this afternoon. I compliment Senator Brown and thank him for his promise to support the amendments being moved by the Australian Democrats. I believe that that is a very appropriate thing for the Greens to be doing. We certainly appreciate that support.

speech.para: Some months ago in this place, I spoke on similar legislation that was before parliament and pointed out that we are contravening a principle that is at least 3,000 years old. The Judaeo‐Christian ethic is very clear on the support which is called for from people who espouse that ethic, particularly in relation to refugees, to those who are strangers in our midst. It is in a phrase which is repeated over and over again, in both the Hebrew scriptures and the Christian scriptures. I will give you an example of what I am referring to.

talk.start.para: —In Hebrew?
—I am not very fluent in Hebrew but, if you want me to give it to you in Greek, I could perhaps do that. The text says:

break.para: The Lord defends the rights of orphans and widows. He cares for foreigners and gives them food and clothing. And you should also care for them, because you were foreigners in Egypt.

This was an absolute paradigm for the Hebrew people because they themselves had been refugees and strangers in a foreign land. So they were called particularly to care for and give support to the strangers in their midst. We can trace the Old Testament of the Hebrew scriptures right through to the New Testament and find this principle espoused over and over again. Because I gave that whole interpretation last time at some length, I will not do it today. But I invite senators to go back and read my speech on that occasion.

In dealing with the issue of refugees and migrants, or foreigners, if you like, as I said before, we are talking about an example that goes back to the absolute paradigmatic history of Israel. In being rescued from Egypt, this became a fundamental principle for them in their relationships with other people and other nations. When they are reminded that they should care for foreigners in their own land because they were foreigners in Egypt, what is touched on is a fundamental paradigm of their history, which is taken up, of course, in the New Testament and in the Christian ethic as well.
One of the most fundamental parables of Jesus spoke about the importance of caring for people who are hungry, thirsty and who are strangers. In that parable, Jesus says:
. . . and you did not welcome me . . . Truly I tell you, just as you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to me.
Foreigners and strangers are regarded fundamentally as those whom Jesus would have us care for.

But in this legislation an attempt has been made to say to people, `Yes, you can come here, but make sure you don't get into any trouble because, if you do, we ain't going to help you; for two years you're on your own.'
I am afraid that if I were to be on my own for two years, I do not think I could survive.
Let me go on. In an article taken from a Catholic magazine that was sent to me, we read words like this:

Migration is, in fact, a central Christian metaphor. God is imaged as a free spirit wandering over the face of the earth . . . who visits Abraham as three itinerants . . . The Holy Family are refugees, fleeing to Egypt from Herod's `killing fields' . . . Jesus, rejected by his compatriots, moves from town to town and `has nowhere to rest his head' . . . Migrants can be to us, then, icons of Jesus and a stimulus to compassion out of love for him.

The scriptures are full of stories of migrants and refugees. Abraham is called to leave his homeland and go to a land he knows not; the people of Israel wander as nomads from place to place, settling in Egypt and then fleeing as refugees; and later their kingdom is invaded and they are carried into exile. Early Christian missionaries such as Paul were itinerants relying on the hospitality of those they visited. This migrant experience became a key metaphor for the life‐journey of every child of God in both the Old and New Testaments. Thus Christians are described as `aliens' even in their own land, as they focus on that other kingdom beyond . . . Thus a second century author described the Christians as `permanent migrants' and the Second Vatican Council as `a pilgrim people'.
Let me quote from Pope John Paul II:
Contemporary Catholic social teaching offers many insights on issues such as the rights of migrants and the duties of others towards them—
many of which have been drawn upon in the paper from which I am quoting. This article continues:
As Pope John Paul II said in 1990:

"Those who sincerely accept this aspect of the message of salvation cannot be lacking in courage and the necessary perseverance to promote the welcome of foreigners. Everyone must have a conversion of heart and there must be a conversion among communities as well.

And I tell you, we sure need that conversion in the Australian community today because, if we do not have it, we will continue with the divisions which have so plagued us in the last few months—divisions in which there are two classes of citizens: those who are Australians, and the rest who some Australians would want to leave this country. Further:

This conversion will be real when people understand that service to one's brothers and sisters is
not merely a secondary `good deed', but that it is strictly tied to the personal relationship of the Christian with his or her Lord, the Good Shepherd . . . "
We could keep quoting from Pope John Paul II, but let me draw on a paper from the Uniting Church—and, Senator Tambling, I am sure you would be interested in this one.

talk.start.para: —I think we shared the same Bible readings yesterday.
—I know you preached yesterday; I wish I had been there to hear the sermon. The Uniting Church says:

break.para:
.
The Government's changes to the Family Reunion migration program will result in the separation of families for lengthy periods, at a time when the family is particularly vulnerable. There will also be some cases when the family will never be able to reunite at all.

.
The changes not only violate basic human rights but also the very core of the right of the Church to protect its people from oppression and suffering.

I would add that after the Second World War the World Council of Churches was one of the foremost agencies in bringing to this country many thousands of migrants. In fact, one of those was a small group of White Russians who settled in a little town called Yarwun in central Queensland whom I visited and who still retain much of their culture and add to the colour, vibrancy and vitality of that community as they share their culture with other Australians.

talk.start.para: —Did they vote Democrat?
—I am not sure whom they voted for; I did not ask them that. The Uniting Church continues:

break.para:
.
These changes are a blatant contradiction to the government's policy to "preserve the unity of family"—
and I think I want to underline that for the government—

.
Based on the common concerns expressed by the community, the changes to immigration laws are:

para.tab: anti-family
unAustralian
inhuman and irresponsible
based on the government's unfounded and failing economic rationalist priority.

break.para: Let me talk about some of the facts of the case. Let me talk about the harsh effect of the changes upon newly arrived refugees. From 3 July 1996 only Australian citizens can sponsor other family members to live in Australia. This will apply to all family, including spouses and dependent children, no matter what age. There will be no exceptions to this rule. Hence, it will apply to people who come to Australia under the refugee and humanitarian program and also to those who are recognised as refugees from within Australia. It takes a minimum of two years to become eligible to apply for Australian citizenship.

Many refugees are separated from their spouses and children when fleeing persecution; their greatest wish after finding safety in Australia is to be reunited with them. However, under the new system they will not be able to sponsor for at least two years. The separation of families, especially parents from their children, in such traumatic circumstances is intolerable. This concern applies to all refugees, whether they have been granted refugee visas before or after arrival in Australia.

Let me give you a real life story—not an imaginary Wright family story or an imaginary research and development illustration, but a real life story: the story of Ali. He came to Australia as a refugee in April 1996. In his country he had been kept under house arrest prior to UNHCR negotiating his release and resettlement. When fleeing to Australia, he left behind his wife and six-year-old daughter. He had been assured by the Australian embassy that he would be able to sponsor his family to join him after he arrived in Australia. He must now wait over two years before seeing his wife and child again. Is the government ashamed of itself? It jolly well ought to be.

Let me read from the refugee and migrant services magazine of the National Council of Churches in Australia. This magazine, I might add, is the magazine of all the major churches in Australia—Roman Catholic, Orthodox, most of the Protestant churches, Quakers, et cetera. It says:
The National Council of Churches in Australia is concerned that migrants who already speak English will be favoured in the new program.

So we are not simply talking about whether or not this is an overall policy; we are really talking about a policy which is quite discriminatory. There is already a lack of recognition of overseas qualifications. If this situation is compounded by the higher points of the English language, it will particularly disadvantage people from non‐English speaking backgrounds. Even though the capacity to speak English does increase the economic viability of a migrant, the primary goal of the family reunion program should be to maintain family ties rather than focus specifically on improving Australia's labour pool. This particular appeal is an appeal to the government of course, but it is also an appeal to the Labor Party, who are very half‐hearted in the amendments that they are proposing.

The National Council of Churches in Australia is particularly troubled by the manner in which the new changes to the family reunion program and the overall size and composition of the migration program were announced. Information on the different aspects of the migration program and policy changes was not announced in a cohesive manner. This created confusion and anxiety in the wider community, which in turn encouraged racist remarks and xenophobic attitudes from anti‐migration and anti‐Asian lobby groups. Community groups would have appreciated being consulted before the changes were made. This would have given the government an opportunity to explain the rationale behind the changes, and it would have allowed input from the communities to be taken into account. But none of that from this government. It seems that successive governments take great pride in the multicultural nature of this country. Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had to defend that very policy this week. But I am afraid his words will ring very hollow when this particular policy, if it is passed, is known in Asian countries. They will compare what he is saying with what his government is doing. They will see the vast difference between the two things.

Once again the government has failed to effectively illustrate the positive aspects of immigration to the Australian public. The public needs to be aware of the reasoning behind Australia's migration program in order not to be confused over the issues. Public opinion, as shown by one recent public opinion poll, has been used by the government as justification for the new cutbacks. In other words, when the government wants to it is prepared to say that racism is not on its agenda and that multiculturalism is its policy. But, when it suits the government, the government is prepared to use racist public opinion as justification for its own policy. A misinformed public may send the wrong signals to its leaders, especially if attempts to clear up confusion over the issues have been unsuccessful.

I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I am very disillusioned by this particular piece of legislation. It really does underline the fundamental failure of this government to understand anything about what it means to have social justice and equity and fairness in this country, particularly for those who are most vulnerable. I hope the government stands convicted by history when we look back and see what we have done to the people in our midst who, indeed, are the most vulnerable.

speech.speaker: McKiernan, Sen James

talk.start.para: —I rise to join in this debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 with a great deal of sadness—sadness about what the contents of the bill reflect and, more importantly, about what is happening in the wider community. I am referring, of course, to the debate on racism, which is a debate we should not be having. Australia should not be having this debate at the moment. If we had a strong Prime Minister in this country, I am sure we would not be having the debate that we are having.

speech.para:
The previous speakers—particularly Senator Brown and Senator Woodley—referred to the debate. Senator Brown, in fact, named Ms Hanson, a member in the other place. I, as other senators have done, have disassociated
myself from the remarks that are attributed to that honourable member. Indeed, I condemn many of the remarks that she has made. I will not go so far here now as to condemn others who are not taking the same position as me in this matter—others with the responsibility to come out and condemn. But I hope that the message will filter through to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that he is the political leader of this country and that he should exercise some leadership in this. That is a faint hope.

We—the Labor members of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—reflected on matters such as this in our minority report, which was presented to the parliament in September this year. In the opening comments of that minority report we drew attention to what had been a sustained attack on migrants to Australia and their families by this government in the short period of time that this government had been in office. We drew attention to the fact that the Office of Multicultural Affairs, which was formerly an integral part of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, had been effectively abolished. We noted that the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research had been abolished. Everybody—even those on the government side, I think—recognised the invaluable contribution that those bodies had made to the exercise of government policies and to the community as a whole with high quality research and policy advice on areas affecting new migrants. In our minority report we drew attention to the fact that services had been cut. We drew attention to the fact that resources under the SIP English language programs had been halved for 1996‐97 and were to be abolished next year. We drew attention to cutbacks in labour market programs. Charges to the adult migration education programs are proposed to increase by over 200 per cent. So what we have seen today is not something that is happening in isolation. It is, indeed, as our opening remarks drew attention to, a sustained attack on migrants and their families. What is really bad is that it is happening in an environment which was caused by comments by a member of the other place whose comments remain on the record. They have not been
repudiated by the Prime Minister of this country.

In this place I have previously spoken about and drawn attention to many newspaper articles of condemnation of the Prime Minister for not taking a stronger line on the Hanson affair. I am not going to repeat them all here today, but I am going to draw attention to an article that appeared in the
Sydney Morning Herald
just two days ago, on Saturday 23 November 1996, headed, `Letter comes back to haunt Howard'. I quote from the beginning of the article:
The Prime Minister's role in the debate over race and immigration is likely to flare again after a letter surfaced showing his strong support for policies of assimilation and integration.
The letter, obtained by the Nine Network and aired last night, has Mr Howard writing to a constituent in May 1991 expressing his personal opposition to multiculturalism.
"My own view on this issue is that Australia made an error in abandoning its former policy of encouraging assimilation and integration in favour of multiculturalism," Mr Howard wrote.
"I do not mind where immigrants come from. However, once in Australia, the goal must surely be to establish a completely cohesive integrated society and not encourage separatism."
The article goes on:

Multiculturalism, a policy originally developed by the Fraser Government, acknowledges the right of all Australians to express and share their cultural heritage, while assimilation places a much stronger onus on migrants to blend into society.

The letter was written when Mr Howard was a frontbencher in the Hewson-led Opposition and after the 1988 furore sparked by his comments about the need to slow Asian immigration in the interests of social cohesion.

When he reclaimed the Opposition leadership, Mr Howard admitted he had erred in making the comments, describing them as "wrong" and "clumsy". But doubts have remained about his commitment to multiculturalism.

While the Coalition criticised the Keating Government's approach to multiculturalism, it remained a part of the Coalition's platform for the 1996 election. However, the Howard-led Government has dismantled the Office of Multicultural Affairs, reducing it to a small branch within the Department of Immigration.
Mr Howard also opposed the use of the term multiculturalism in the joint resolution passed by the Parliament last month deploring racism.
The appearance of the letter will add to Mr Howard's problems on the eve of his attendance at the APEC summit in Manila.
A spokesman for Mr Howard declined to comment on the letter last night, saying he could not contact the Prime Minister as he was en route to Manila.

It is unfortunate that we have to be debating and drawing reference to these matters whilst those important talks are taking place in Manila—important for each and every Australian. But we should not have our neighbours being given the opportunity to further criticise Australia on the matter of race. Indeed we know that many of our neighbouring countries are very upset about what has been happening of recent time in this country.

I want to come back to the bill, to the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and to recognise the presence in the chamber of Senator Ellison, the chair of that committee, and Senator Abetz. They will recall that I expressed my pleasant surprise with the recommendations that the majority of the committee brought into the committee when we were deliberating on the report. Their actions in adopting some of the recommendations given to the committee in the various public hearings that were conducted and the submissions that the committee received during the inquiry are an indication—if one was needed, and I am not sure it is—of the good work that committees can engage in and can undertake on behalf of the parliament.

I think there is physical evidence of that good work now in the sense that some of the concerns that were raised to the committee in the public hearings were listened to by the majority of the committee and indeed were then in turn listened to by the minister after the majority report was tabled in the parliament. But, unfortunately, as usual the considerations do not go far enough. The majority has not yet explained the breach of election commitments that the government has engaged in with this bill.

para.break: Prior to the 1996 election there was a six-month waiting period for the jobsearch allowance, the newstart allowance, the youth training allowance, the parenting allowance, the sickness allowance and the witness allow ance. The government indicated in the election campaign that they would extend the six-month waiting period to two years. But the government have extended it way beyond the six or seven areas where the six-month waiting period applied. They extended it to the carers pension, the child disability allowance, the disability wage supplement, the double orphan allowance, the family payment, the guardian allowance, the health care card and a whole range of other benefits which were never mentioned by the coalition in the election campaign. They were not part of the shonky promises that were made to the community in the election campaign of February-March this year.

speech.para: The Australian Democrats and I think Senator Brown pleaded with the opposition, with the Labor Party, to join them in total opposition to the bill. We will not be doing that. We will be sticking with the recommendations that we have put in the minority report. We will not be breaching one of the commitments we gave in the election campaign and indeed the legislation that we brought into this place in 1992 which put in place the six-month waiting period that applied from 1 January 1993.

Briefly, in the debates within Labor Party caucus and the caucus committees the support for these measures was not unanimous. Nonetheless, at the end of the day the numbers were there within the party to bring in those provisions. Senators on the other side of the chamber, as we were then, supported the legislation to impose this six-month waiting period. It would be hypocritical of me to stand aside from the votes in which I participated in 1992 in relation to this matter, so I will stick with the principled position that we adopted. We will seek to hold, by way of the amendments we intend to move and the way we will vote on government amendments, the government to the promises and commitments that they made at election time.

I mentioned in passing the shonky figures. In a coalition statement issued before the budget, the now government said they were going to save $616 million as a consequence of extending the six-month waiting period to two years. The committee, in its deliberations
in June this year, was given different information. We were told, for example, in the explanatory memorandum that accompanied the bill—there are details of this on page 9 of the majority report—that in the year 1996-97 the provisions would save $31.4 million; in 1997-98, $143.5 million; and, in 1998-1999, $185 million. That totals $360.5 million—quite a distance from the $616 million that was promised in the `Meeting our Commitments' statement.

The budget statement came up with another figure. I will not go through the amounts for the individual years, but the total was $520.2 million. I note that, in the list of government amendments that have been circulated, the additional measures that the majority of the committee has been able to make the government accept cut those savings by some half a million dollars in each of the next two years. I do not believe that is good enough.

I endorse the comments of Senator Bolkus, who led the debate for this side, on the Racial Discrimination Act and the fact that we would like to ensure, by way of an amendment we seek to move to this bill, that nothing we do to this bill this afternoon or tomorrow will in any way contravene the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act. We are seeking to move an amendment in that light.

We listened carefully to the evidence presented to us by the Racial Discrimination Commissioner, Ms Zita Antonios, who provided us with evidence, I think in Sydney. We also noted, and drew attention to on page 5 of the minority report, the prevarication, if you like, of the Attorney‐General's Department when they were questioned on what the Racial Discrimination Commissioner said. We would like to put this matter beyond doubt. Even if the racial discrimination debate was not currently taking place in our community, I think there is an obligation on the parliament, on this Senate, to carry that amendment when it is put to us.

In conclusion, Mr Acting Deputy President, I again draw attention to the minority report that we submitted in September this year. I have not dealt with each and every matter in the minority report; it runs to some 16 pages. I commend it to the parliament. One area that
was not properly addressed in this speech was how the provisions of this bill, if enacted, will discriminate against individuals. In one of the appendices that we attached to our minority report, we provided information on currency restrictions that various countries impose on their nationals as they leave.

People leaving the United Kingdom have no restrictions on the amount of currency that they can bring with them. However, the most a person coming from Vietnam can bring with them is $US5,000. All a person can take from the Philippines is 5,000 pesos, which, at the time we were preparing the report, amounted to $A243. Other provisions worth mentioning concern India, the People's Republic of China, South Africa and Iraq. I dare say that, had we more time, we could have looked at a number of other countries.

Clearly, these provisions are discriminatory. As a nation, we cannot address what the Philippines determine that their nationals should take out of the country, but we do have to be aware that these restrictions are in place and that a migrant coming from the Philippines, China or Vietnam should have the same rights of settlement in Australia as a person coming from the United Kingdom or, indeed, the Republic of Ireland. It is going to be a fairly arduous committee stage debate on this matter. It is something that I look forward to, although I would have preferred that it happen in a different environment than the one that currently exists in our community.

speech.speaker: Ellison, Sen Chris

talk.start.para:
—The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 was introduced into the Senate in May 1996 as part of the government's commitment to a pre-election policy that new entrants to Australia should provide for their own support during their first two years here. The bill amends the Social Security Act 1991 and other related bills to extend the newly arrived residents waiting period for certain social security payments from six months to two years for migrants who arrived in Australia on or after 1 April this year. It also makes
amendments to these acts to ensure that these provisions are more workable.

speech.para: The bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in May and was reported on in September. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the majority of the committee made a number of recommendations which have been taken up by the government and accepted. Before I touch on them, let me deal with a number of concerns that have been mentioned today. One of them relates to racial discrimination. I might say at the outset that the committee relied on the evidence of Professor Ivan Shearer and the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that the bill does not discriminate on the grounds of race or contravene international obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

Furthermore, concerns were raised in relation to retrospectivity. I am pleased to put to bed any concerns of that sort. The committee noted these and looked at that subject. It stated that, in its view, these provisions were clearly enunciated during the election campaign. Information on the proposed changes to the policy were widely circulated by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The committee noted that the provisions in this bill relating to special benefits are prospective and that new residents who arrive on or after 1 April 1996 will be eligible for special benefits under the current arrangements. Therefore, for those reasons, the committee was of the view that there was no retrospective effect in relation to this bill. This policy achieved a good deal of attention in the run-up to the March election.

I mentioned that other recommendations were made by the majority. These related in part to the carers pension, the child disability allowance, the double orphan pension, the innocent illegals category of migrants and interdependent relationships. There was a lot more detail to it than that. I recommend to anyone interested in this area to read the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Suffice it to say that a number of groups gave evidence in relation to these areas of concern. This was taken up
by the committee and acted upon by the government.

I might also add that the majority of the committee recommended that some guidelines be set down by the secretary to the department in relation to the definition of `family members'. Furthermore, as the two-year waiting period commences on the date of arrival in Australia or the granting of permanent resident status, the committee was of the view that any appeal provision should not unfairly interfere with the rights or situation of any appellant in relation to their status. For this reason, an amendment has been included to provide that if a decision not to grant a visa is overturned, the period will commence on the day it was initially refused. That concern was raised in the course of evidence and has been met by the majority report of the committee.

I must also make it clear that this bill does not affect in any way the refugee or humanitarian programs which are currently in place. It does not detract from those in any form whatsoever and I think it is important that it not do so. At the end of the day we have a bill which strikes a balance between allowing for equity in dealing with those who fall within the exceptional categories that I have mentioned in part and the need to allow for responsible control of government expenditure in this area.

Substantial savings will accrue on the passing of this bill. That will mean that the huge deficit which this government inherited in March this year can be partly addressed. The government looked not only at financial considerations but also at the matters that I raised earlier—in much more detail than I have enunciated here today—relating to exceptional circumstances, including such areas of concern as the carers pension, just to name one.

So, therefore, there is a balance. I reject entirely the proposition that this is a bill which has not looked at these exceptional circumstances. There is a balance between controlling government expenditure and looking at the more human aspects which can touch on the area of immigration in these circumstances.

break.para: The previous government saw fit to impose a six‐month waiting period. This government in the run up to the election announced that its policy would be that this period would be extended to two years. It was on that basis that it was elected to power. I do not think you can get a clearer mandate than that.

speech.speaker: Cooney, Sen Barney

talk.start.para: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 we are now considering amends the Social Security Act 1991, the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, the Data‐matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1995 and the Health Insurance Act 1973. This bill will amend legislation which is itself going to be amended by requests to be moved on behalf of the government. There are some proposed amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats and by the opposition, but I think those are going to have little chance of passing.

speech.para: Nevertheless, it is legislation that has been put forward and, before it becomes law, will be amended further. It is to be amended partly because of the work of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which is chaired by Senator Ellison, who has just spoken. He himself has said that there was a need to make changes to the proposed amendments because the proposed amendments as they originally stood were too harsh.

Having looked at the amendments put forward on behalf of the government, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Tambling) to find out before this comes on for debate in the committee stage what proposed division 18 refers to. It seems to be referring to clause 94. If the parliamentary secretary could find out what legislation division 18, schedule 1A refers to, it would be very helpful for debate on this matter.

As Senator Ellison and other speakers have said, this is a matter of balancing good government in terms of financial management against good government in terms of looking after people who come and live here. Senator McKiernan, who is not a bleeding heart, but
is very wise in this area and has been interested in it for many years, has said that this does not strike the proper balance between good government in terms of economic management and good government in terms of looking after people who come here to live, because, as has already been said, it imposes obligations on people who come here that are not imposed on others. That imposition is the necessity to exist without any assistance from the community at a time when people are most vulnerable—and Senator Brown brought this out.

If it is the intention of this legislation to save money, then perhaps a better way round would be to give people the support they need when they get here and ask for repayment of that money when they have been able to set themselves up and are in a better position to return the money taken from the community. That is not a new concept by any means. We have HECS where we enable people to study at universities—to give them the skills needed to make this country the sort of country we want it to be—by giving them support when they most need it and we ask those students to pay back the money when they are in a better position to do so. Why that concept is not used in this circumstance I am really unable to see.

People who get here from overseas, who are brought here in accordance with the law and who come here as lawful migrants are most likely to be trying to find out how the country runs and what the culture of the country is. They are probably trying to get themselves a job, trying to find out how to accommodate to the customs of the place and perhaps trying to skill themselves in English during those first two years. Why, when there are alternatives to this, do we impose upon them the hardship of coping without any support from the community? After all, they are to become our fellows as time goes by. Indeed, as I understand the situation, they become our fellows as soon as they get here.

People who are either resident in the country on a permanent basis or citizens of the country have a right, I think, to expect that we will not leave them in distress. Social security is simply that—giving security to
people who are in need of it because it binds up the social fabric of the country in which we live.

What we are doing with this legislation is simply saying, `You people may be in need, you may need disability wage supplements, you may need all sorts of things, but we are not going to give them to you because you are in a particular category,' even though there are some pensions which we say they ought to get, the double orphan's pension for example. Why is that made an exception? Does somebody without a job have any greater or lesser need than somebody who needs a double orphan's pension?

Why is there this scheme which picks and chooses between those who are in need? If you are in need, you are in need. People recognise that. The government in its original proposals for this bill recognised that. The government members of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee understood that. In fact, they made suggestions that this support be extended to a larger category of people than the government had originally suggested. That has been done by the government. The minority said that there were other categories.

It seems to me extraordinary that we should say there should be choices made between people who are in need, by definition—that is what this is all about—so that some are allowed to get the lifeline and others are not when they will all ultimately become part of this community in which we live. We have got them at their most vulnerable: in the first two years they are here. How do we face them 10 years later when they are great contributors to this society? Do we say to them, `We are a bit sorry about those first two years. That is how things come. We had to make a choice. We had to save a certain amount of money and, unfortunately, your need, at the time desperate, could not be fulfilled'?

Page 9 of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report sets out the amounts of savings the government envisages will be made as a result of this legislation. As I understand it, it is an amount of some millions of dollars overall, but in
respect of certain categories it is quite small. In relation to the double orphan's pension, for example, `negligible' is the word put beside each of the four financial years after this one. It is probably for that reason that the double orphan's pension has been taken off the list of those to which migrants will not be entitled in the first two years of their coming here.

I suggest to the government that they look carefully at these categories generally to see if there cannot be at least more added to those that are exempt from this fairly rigorous legislation, which is going to deprive some people who have come here to live as residents and ultimately citizens of this country of assistance to help them through their hard times.

A lot of quite emotional words have been said in this debate. I think that is proper because it is an emotional issue. We are talking about stopping the sorts of people that have made this country what it is—we have talked about them—gaining access to the benefits that citizens and residents here can expect.

They are the latest in a wave of migration that goes back a long time and which has contributed mightily to this country. Wave after wave of migration has met an at times unfriendly reception in this place. Migrants have made this country what it is. Of course, I do not leave out from the considerations here the original inhabitants of this place. Great contributions have been made by migrants over the years. I think it looks very ill, if you sit back and consider this, that those of us whose ancestors have been here for a long time in many cases have nevertheless benefited from more recent waves of migration.

In three years time it will be 150 years since the last of my overseas ancestors came to this land. I think you have to agree that in those 150 years the economic, cultural, moral and even religious quality of this country has gone up in leaps and bounds. It is a much better place to live in than was then the case. It seems now that, if you look at those generations, suddenly we of this generation say, `Those that come now are not going to enjoy
the benefits that those of us who had ancestors that came before do.'

I was just reading an article written by James Jupp in the
ANU Reporter
published on 13 November 1996. James Jupp is the Director of the Centre for Immigration and Multicultural Studies in the research school of social sciences.

talk.start.para: —Excellent.
—As Senator Conroy says, an excellent man. In the article, headed up `Shades of Enoch Powell: Pauline Hanson's star will also fade', he states:

speech.para: Talk of being "flooded" by Asians ignores the fact that immigration control in Australia is now tighter than for 50 years for all except New Zealanders. Talk of Asian "cultures" being incompatible with "mainstream" Australia ignores the fact that large proportions of Asian immigrants (other than refugees and their relatives) are English‐speaking Christians.

The point I want to make is not so much about the people coming from Asia but the fact that we are now operating, according to Dr Jupp, under immigration control which is tighter than it has been for 50 years. It seems extraordinary that we are reducing the number of migrants that come here every year but nevertheless we are imposing these hardships upon them.

The previous government had a six‐month waiting period for migrants. I want to say two things about that. Firstly, two years is four times greater than six months, which is obvious, and it would be easier to cope with six months than two years. Secondly, I am not sure that imposing six months upon migrants was a good thing in any event.

para.break: When you look at this hit on the very sort of people who, apart from the original habitants, have come to this country and established their families, who have brought up their children—who have brought up their children in turn—for a number of generations, and when you look at the sort of people who got the place going and who are being picked out for particular attention so that there can be some savings to the budget, you begin to wonder about the balance that is to be made between the government's responsibility to the budget and the government's responsibili ty to our people and the people who have established non-Aboriginal culture here. You certainly think this legislation weighs too heavily in favour of what is called fiscal responsibility.

speech.para: If we should be doing one thing with public funds, if we should be doing one thing with the taxpayers' dollar, it is making sure we have a society that is cohesive and cared for and that when properly looked after can make their contribution later during their stay here. Let us look after these people now and let them, if we so require, pay back that help at a later stage when they are better able to do so.

speech.speaker: Abetz, Sen Eric

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996. In doing so, let me try to debunk some of the commentary that was introduced by those opposite concerning the approach by the coalition to migrants.

speech.para: There was inherent in a lot of the comments the suggestion that the coalition was somehow anti-migrant, that somehow we did not acknowledge the achievements that migrants have made to this great country. The fact that I am standing here in this place today is indicative of the fact that the Liberal Party does recognise those contributions.

The fact that Mr Zammit, the member for Lowe, and Mrs Johnston, the member for Canning, being overseas born and from a non-English speaking background like me, find themselves in this parliament I think is sufficient proof to indicate that we do have the proper humanitarian standards required in making the migrant community in this country feel welcomed. There is, I would suggest, a big difference in as much as we do not try to be paternalistic to them but rather want to deal with them on the basis of their being Australian.

para.break: I embark upon the next part of my speech with some reluctance. Each time there is a debate about migration in this place we unfortunately see the Labor Party descend to a commentary bordering on racism, trying to hold themselves up as the party that is not for racist views and thereby, by implication, suggest ing that those of us on this side of the chamber somehow do wish to give credibility to those views. Of course Senator McKiernan's contribution was very much along those lines.

speech.para: I do not know which past Labor leader those opposite would want me to refer to but Arthur Calwell had a few very choice words to say. He was a man whom Senator Cooney defended in this chamber only last year by saying what a magnificent individual he was in supporting multiculturalism in this country. Do you want a few quotes of what Arthur Calwell said? He said things like `Japanese women ought not be allowed to pollute our shores.' There are a whole lot of others. I only have another six minutes, so I will not go through Arthur Calwell's record.

You then can read former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's comments, not from me but from the Clyde Cameron diaries. He referred to refugees as the Vietnamese Balts, referring to the Baltic refugees. Vietnamese Balts—how denigrating can that be, not of migrants but refugees, upon whom I hasten to add this legislation does not impact at all? Or we can go to comments of former Prime Minister Keating who said the famous words, `After all, the best migrant is the infant Australian.'

If the Labor Party want to hector us on each and every occasion migration comes up, we will embrace that debate and quote back the shameful record of their past leaders. The reality is that this is simply a piece of legislation which has no foundation on the basis of some misunderstanding or dislike of migrants. In fact, it is legislation which is designed to ease part of the burden which our economy can no longer bear. Why is it that the economy can no longer bear the burden? It is because of the spendthrift nature of those opposite when they were in power. If they wanted Australia to be able to afford to continue to fund migrants as we have done in the past, they should have thought about that before they got us into the huge debt that we are now in.

We on this side of the chamber have to get Australia out of debt. It is interesting to note that those opposite implemented a decision which required migrants to support themselves for the first six months after their arrival in
Australia. That was after the 1993 federal election when they had made not a single noise about their intentions during the election campaign. They kept that one in the bottom drawer. There was not a word in their policy platform. They realised the financial mess that they were getting themselves into. They were trying to retrieve some money and, as a result, introduced the six‐month rule. So they were the ones who set the precedent and said it was fair and reasonable.

Senator Cooney's speech was quite moving until you realised that Senator Cooney and his colleagues voted for the six‐month rule. It really does beg the question: why the crocodile tears now? Why weren't there crocodile tears in 1993? Why weren't there crocodile tears when you were acting in the spendthrift way which bankrupted this country and has made us, unfortunately, impose some of these measures. It is no good trying to say to us now that we have to look after them. The reality is that we cannot. I do not think it is unfair if we do not look after them, given the structure of the legislation.

It was very interesting to listen to Senator McKiernan's contribution in which he suggested that somehow it would be just and reasonable for the Labor Party to vote for only those aspects of this legislation which we had specifically enunciated during the federal election campaign. If that is the way they are going to act in this chamber, they should be embracing the Telstra one‐third sale absolutely. But no, they will not adopt that principle for Telstra. They adopt this principle only when it suits them. Of course, if you adopt a principle only when it suits you, it belies the fact that it is not a principle at all; it is just cheap politicking—and the Labor Party has been exposed for that.

The Senate committee which looked at this legislation, of which I was a member and formed part of the majority, made a number of recommendations to the government which, we believe, would make it fairer and more reasonable. I am glad to say that the government has accepted those recommendations. Rather than dealing with some of the emotion in this issue, it might be interesting to deal with some of the facts. For example, newly
arrived residents generally have higher rates of dependants on social security than do the general population. In the longitudinal survey of immigration to Australia, it was found that the overall unemployment rate for newly arrived residents was 39 per cent. You have to ask whether, in the current economic climate, we as a nation can continue to afford that.

The Labor government clearly came to the conclusion that they could no longer afford that sort of support and, therefore, made the rule 26 weeks. We are putting it out to 104 weeks. But those under the refugee and humanitarian program will not, in any way, be adversely affected by this. These conditions will apply to only those migrants who come here on the basis that they can look after themselves.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

speech.speaker: Eggleston, Sen Alan

talk.start.para: —A couple of weeks ago, the annual report of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation was tabled in the Senate. I was interested in this because, by coincidence, my Perth office is on the same floor of the Exchange Plaza as Austrade and EFIC, as it is known. It seemed to me that EFIC was a fairly obscure government agency but, having read through the report, I would like to put on record that I greatly admire the contribution EFIC is making towards facilitating Australia's export drive to all parts of the world. It is very clear that EFIC is playing a very important role in promoting Australia's export trade internationally, in particular within the European and Asian markets. EFIC is doing an outstanding job in this area.

speech.para:
According to EFIC's annual report, the corporation supported an incredible $7.5 billion in exports in 1995‐96, which was an increase of some 20 per cent in the support they had given to Australian exports over the previous year. It shows that the work EFIC is
doing in financing insurance for Australian exports is really vital to the international economy that Australia seeks to become a part of.

EFIC support goes mostly to small and medium sized companies. For example, over the last year, as I said, the total value of exports that they supported was $7.5 billion, but that included $2.935 billion to Europe, $2.227 billion to Asia, and $1.173 billion to the Americas—which is, interestingly, made up of $949 million to North America and $224 million to South America—and also includes exports to the Middle East and to Africa. So EFIC's spectrum is very wide indeed.

The kinds of companies that EFIC has supported include financing a German company's support of fast catamaran ferries for routes on the Baltic Sea to and from Sweden as well as other Baltic ports. Most of their focus, however, in terms of new business is in Asia, which is appropriate when one considers the growth of the economies in that area and their importance to Australia in the long run.

Asia accounted for 30 per cent of the total exports financed by EFIC, and South-East Asian buyers were recipients of 49 per cent of new loans signed. Indonesia was the largest borrower of medium- to long-term finance for Australian exports, while Singapore overtook Malaysia as the largest user of EFIC credit insurance in South-East Asia.

EFIC provided financial services to people who wished to export across the whole spectrum of South-East Asia, India, North Asia, China and Japan. Support was given for loans to China for 15 telecommunications and water treatment plants, which amounted to some $83 million in export value to Australia, and four export working capital guarantees were issued for things as diverse as mining machinery, pumps, packaging and brewing machinery—Australia, obviously, being a world leader in the technology of brewing.

In the case of Japan, credit insurance for exports to Japan increased by some $231 million, covering things such as dairy and machinery products. In addition, seven working capital guarantees were issued covering
contracts for aerospace equipment, car parts, motor cycles, audio editing equipment and canned beer. It just shows what a wide spectrum of activities EFIC does support, including, as I said, exports to places as diverse as the Middle East, Africa and South America—where three loans were signed for the export of agricultural machinery to Argentina and another loan provided for the provision and installation of telephone switches in the same country.

The Middle East is a growth area for EFIC with export credit insurance increasing by 45 per cent over the last year, and four export working capital guarantees were issued for Saudi Arabia, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates. It is interesting to compare the current record of the Australian merchandise export portfolio to various regions of the world with what it was 20 years ago. The figures reveal the changing pattern of Australia's involvement with the rest of the world and our growing engagement with Asia.

In 1975, the Asian region as a whole accounted for 47.2 per cent of Australian merchandise exports compared with 63 per cent in 1995. Western Europe received 17 per cent of our merchandise exports in 1975, but this is now down to 12.3 per cent. Eastern Europe represented 4.7 per cent in 1975, but in 1995 that was only 0.6 per cent. The North American free trade area accounted for 12.8 per cent of our merchandise exports in 1975, but that is now down to 9.5 per cent.

These relative changes in percentages reflect the growth of Asia, particularly South-East Asia and North Asia, in importance as destinations for Australian exports. They are undoubtedly a measure of the success of Australia's push into the region following the British entry into the Common Market in the early 1970s. They also reflect the spectacular growth of some of the nations and their economies in the Asian region. It is interesting to note that, excluding Japan, the East Asian regional economies have grown by an average of 9.4 per cent since 1990. There is no doubt that this growth signals great opportunities for Australian industry and business.

para.break: In conclusion, I would like to say and put on the record that I greatly admire the import ant contribution that this small office on the same floor as I occupy in Perth is making to the Australian economy and to our export drive. I would like to put on record the fact that EFIC supports exports to some 155 countries either through insuring the exporter against non-payment by the buyer, which is credit insurance, or through providing finance for capital goods. As I said, I think they are doing a great job. They certainly deserve to be recognised for what they are doing.

speech.speaker: Bishop, Sen Mark

talk.start.para: —I want to talk today about the effect that the Howard budget will have on the Western Australian economy. While it is important to note that Western Australians will be affected by changes in a general sense, like citizens in all other states, there are some particularly damaging aspects for Western Australia in this budget. Briefly, I will mention the broad general cuts taking place and then address one or two specific issues of concern.

speech.para: Prescriptions, as we know, will increase to $20. A family with three children, when they all get sick together, as is the norm, will face a bill of $60 in one hit for the prescriptions. Dental care promises by Mr Howard in the last election campaign have been broken and waiting lists for our elderly citizens will increase. The elderly will also be faced with a $34 a day charge for nursing homes when they earn more than $50 a week. This will be on top of the $26,000 up-front fee.

The government's refusal to properly compensate doctors may result in the loss of bulk-billing. The result could be that consultant bills at the doctors will be $10 a visit. On top of this, government supported increases in health insurance premiums will provide no solace in the area of health care. I note reports in newspapers last week which show just how recently the Prime Minister has himself approved health insurance premium increases.

Parents with children in child care will also suffer. They now face increased charges of $21.40 per week for children under three in government child care and $14.35 per week
for children over three. In private child care, these charges will be $19.60 per week for families with children in long day care of 50 hours.

These changes represent a strong ideological point of view. That view is that the government is bad. The objective then is to remove the government from participation in key sectors of the economy. A message I will repeat throughout this speech is that this view held by the government is wrong. We believe that the government does have a role to play in industry, job creation and service provision.

This retreat from government activity in the economy is best evident in my home state of Western Australia. It is particularly true with regard to the shipping bounties. The federal government slashed these in the budget when other competing nations now have a bounty of around 10 per cent. In a number of European countries the bounties have been increased. Termination of this bounty will affect a group of high growth, export oriented manufacturers. This is exactly the section of the economy we want to encourage, not push out of competitive business by slanting the playing field out of their favour.

This decision has resulted in shipping companies in Fremantle such as Austal Ships being unable to compete on a level playing field with its competitors. Whilst this in itself is harmful for the company involved, it also has disastrous ramifications for the Australian economy. The government will be hampering an industry which, through the assistance of the ships bounty, had a growth rate in production of 200 per cent, a growth in exports of 150 per cent and a growth in employment levels of 50 per cent since its inception.

On top of these figures is the way in which they translate to on‐the‐ground effects. In coastal areas such as Fremantle, Rockingham and Mandurah the industry may see a slump. The result will be a drop in income for local areas and a possible loss of jobs for many of the local residents. When the issue of suppliers and support staff is factored into those who will lose from the drop in work for Austal Ships and other such companies, the figures begin to grow.

break.para: However, as if these macro figures were not enough, there is still more. The report which reviewed the government decision to cut the ships bounty is a flawed ideological document. The first surprising figure on which the government has based its decision is the size of the savings by termination of the bounty. The termination of the ships bounty will save the government the total sum of not quite $3 million. When compared to the size of the national economy, this saving is minuscule.

When the size of the saving is compared against the damage which will be done to an important and potential growth area which is export oriented, the decision can be described as nothing other than sad. Stupidity also springs to mind. A paltry $3 million saving is not worth the loss in employment and export dollars generated from this industry. The government fails to realise that continued support of this industry can result in it eventually becoming successful enough to survive in a market without the bounty. However, at this stage it requires a small degree of assistance to get to that level.
Additionally, the report uses as its base some rather dodgy economic assertions. Firstly, the report quotes from a submission from the Bureau of Industry Economics. It states:

All export industries are in direct competition with each other, that is, Australia's ship builders, miners, farmers and tourist operators compete with each other to supply the foreign exchange that Australians use to buy imports.

This a nonsense argument that all export industries are in competition with each other. They are, in fact, in competition for access to markets with other similar industry operators in that field around the world. The competition is between like markets for access rights. The notion that shipbuilders and farmers are competing for access rights with each other illustrates one of two things by the government—either profound stupidity and no understanding of the international economy or a willingness to use any silly argument to justify its ideological policies.

This report that the government relies on is full of such other ridiculous and plain wrong statements and assumptions on which its
decisions are apparently based. There appears to be no real analysis of the industry assistance programs being terminated and the reasons why this should happen or why they should continue. The Senate should be aware that this is not an isolated incident. The same ridiculous cuts founded on poor analysis of the relevant industry is also occurring with the book bounty, computer bounty and the machine tools and robots bounty.

Commitment to this document illustrates two things about the current government. Firstly, there is an inability to think through issues comprehensively with regard to the national economy—a failure which stems from lack of understanding about the forces that drive the engines of growth in our own economy. The second point it illustrates is that this current government understands little about how competitors in South-East Asia manage their economy and, consequently, do not understand how to make the government and its policies work to the advantage of our own domestic industries.

The decision by the government to slash the bounty and retreat from government involvement in this sector may increase unemployment in the Western Australian economy and reduce its export contributions to the nation. The Labor Party rejects this approach by government because we believe that the government does have a critical role to play in assisting industry to build on exports and create employment.

The concern and attitude towards the government stemming from this decision, however, does not stop there. Austal Ships were rightly aggrieved when the government showed their arrogance and lack of interest in industry policy by granting Austal Ships only a 10-minute hearing after they flew all the way from Perth to Canberra at their own expense to argue their case.

The cuts to export oriented markets do not stop there, however. The slashing of the DIFF program has meant that Western Australian companies involved in shipbuilding and construction in other countries has seen their support eroded. The result is a further loss of export dollars and, as a result, employment in Western Australia.

From this an additional question must be asked. Why is the Western Australian Premier, Richard Court, not doing more to save Austal Ships and the local economy? In fact, the role of Mr Court in the whole budget debate needs to be closely examined. It is forecast that the impact of the budget will be felt in early 1997. Coincidentally, the Premier has shifted the Western Australian election from its traditional date of February/March to 14 December of this year. The result will be the state election not coinciding with the initial impact of the budget cuts in Western Australia.

There has been no attempt in Western Australia to diversify the economy from being simply reliant on the resources sector. An export oriented manufacturer such as Austal Ships has been successful at doing this. Their good work is now liable to be destroyed by the actions of the Commonwealth government. The government needs to recognise the role industry policy and support can play in our economy and use it sufficiently to Australia's advantage.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to continue my remarks of 16 October regarding the possible health effects of low level radiofrequency electromagnetic radiation. Over the next three weeks, the Standards Australia subcommittee for non‐ionising radiation will make a decision about a proposal to relax the public exposure standard for radiofrequency microwave radiation by a factor of five—that is, from 200 microwatts per square centimetre to 1,000 microwatts or one milliwatt.

speech.para: I suggest to the government that it should, as a matter of some urgency, request the Standards Australia subcommittee to postpone a final decision on these standards until all of the relevant data has been properly assessed. As I understand it, discussion and decision making processes on the standards subcommittee have essentially taken place behind closed doors away from the scrutiny of the general public, from independent scientists and from concerned interest groups who might hold a different view from that of the industry.

break.para: I ask senators to take note that the standards subcommittee is very heavily weighted with industry representation. They include: the Australian Electronics Industry Association, the Australian Radiation Protection Society, the Civil Aviation Authority, departments of industrial relations and employment in New South Wales, departments of defence and transport and communications, the Institution of Radio and Electronics Engineers of Australia, the National Measurement Laboratory of CSIRO, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, Royal Adelaide Hospital and the Wireless Institute of Australia.

The government is passing its regulatory responsibilities to limit or control emissions of electromagnetic radiation to a body controlled, in this instance, by the very industries which stand to gain from the sales and use of electromagnetic technology. This shift, together with the fact that industry interests ignore warning signs from recent research which points to likely health effects, makes it clear to me that we have an environmental, public and occupational health and planning problem on our hands.

I think it is also fair to say that consultative processes appear to be playing second fiddle to the economic growth and expansion of the telecommunications industry. I have spoken before about why some scientists are concluding that low power density microwaves could pose serious health problems. The current Australian exposure standard is not a standard that takes low level microwaves into account. The exposure standard is a thermal standard, set up by technical and industrial experts at a time when wireless technology was far less developed than it is now. It is more appropriate as a protection for those exposed to very high or occupational levels of microwave radiation.
Professor John Goldsmith, in a recent study about low power density effects, says:

Epidemiology provides a growing number of reports which find health status change, including increased cancers, miscarriage, brain‐activity changes, anxiety, sleep disorders, etc in association with above‐average exposure to radiofrequency and microwave radiation.

In a few days time a conference in Munich will be convening with international delegates, including Australians, to discuss this problem of athermal microwaves on human health. Professor Goldsmith also has this to say about the issue:

There are strong political and economic reasons for needing there to be no health effect of RF/MW exposure, just as there are strong public health reasons for more accurately portraying the risks. Those of us who intend to speak for public health must be ready for opposition that is nominally, but not truly, scientific.

But, to return to the change to the exposure standard, I have been advised that, of non‐industry members voting, CSIRO is opposed to relaxing the standard, on the basis that the science is inadequate to guarantee human safety and, furthermore, that to date there is no operational reason for the change. There is currently no equipment which needs this massive increase, or any increase.

Former chief medical officer of Telstra, Dr Bruce Hocking, has voted no already to the relaxation of the standard, because of uncertainties arising from his recent survey around the TV towers in Sydney. But I understand that the Australian Radiation Laboratory will vote in favour of it. This is quite an interesting position for a Commonwealth government health and radiation safety body to take and I suggest that it is not unreasonable to question whether this might in fact be a failure to act in the interests of the public.

The discussion on this standards subcommittee on whether or not to relax the standard has been fraught with uncertainty both here and in New Zealand and the final outcome of that voting is still not certain. But I remind the Senate that people are being told by industry and by government that our electromagnetic radiation emissions are well within the standard.
In the last few days, Red Hill preschool, in objecting to the installation of a mobile phone tower, have been told by Vodafone:

There are no substantial or convincing biological effects that could lead to adverse health effects including cancer from radiofrequency radiation around base stations. Radiofrequency levels are at least two thousand times below the limit for
continuous public exposure permitted by the current international and national standards.

I ask the Senate to take note that telecommunication carriers are causing considerable community distress and anger with this attitude. It is an attitude which the current legislation has fostered. I suggest to you that feelings out there where people live are reaching boiling point. Week after week, my office receives calls from people who are struggling to come to terms with their inability to get answers from an industry which seems only interested in its own very narrow research. I suggest that not only is a review of the present exposure standard due but also the basic structure of the standards subcommittee needs to be examined to make sure that it is a more balanced and representative body.

I also suggest that it is quite inappropriate for the standard to be relaxed at a time when ongoing research indicates that there may well be serious health effects from accumulated high frequency microwave radiation. Indeed, it would seem prudent in the current climate of concern and uncertainty to tighten rather than relax the standard.

History books have shown that the progress of science depends on the capacity for flexible thinking processes, and we believe that a paradigm shift is now due. The New Zealand Ministry of Health in its recently completed report of August this year, entitled
Literature Review on the health effects of radiofrequency radiation
, said:

Biological plausibility is an important guide to judging causality, but is of limited value in assessing exposures that have been studied for a relatively short period . . . Judgments about the "plausibility" of athermal effects of radiofrequency radiation may be quite different in ten years time than at present.
Continuing from the same report:

There are no well understood biological mechanisms to explain some of the epidemiological findings, but this is not a sufficient reason to reject the evidence. Biological plausibility is a weak criterion for assessing new exposures, and the flaws in the research must be weighed against some consistency in the outcomes. Rather, there is a high level of scientific uncertainty, and the implications for policy making depend largely on where the onus of proof lies: the epidemiological evidence
may be construed as either "incomplete evidence of cause" or "incomplete evidence of safety".

I think there is only one conclusion possible in the light of this report: the Australian government should examine the breakneck speed of the telecommunications industry expansion, including changes to exposure standards, and a prudent avoidance policy should be applied. The eminent ex-CSIRO scientist Les Dalton said:

Above all, we need to question the economic myths that motivate our growth‐oriented and ever more polluting society. Only then will we seriously begin to re‐establish a genuinely healthy relationship with our natural environment.

I suggest that the expansionist philosophy of the telecommunications industry is one such economic myth. Competition, deregulation and privatisation policies are producing a more hazardous, wasteful and environmentally destructive telecommunications industry, and I think it is now time to take stock.

Before I finish, I would like to inform the Senate that Dr Peter French, one of Australia's top medical researchers at the Centre for Immunology in Sydney, whom I mentioned once before, was advised this month that his very important and unique work on electromagnetic radiation and human cells has been refused funding.
(Time expired)
