—Tonight I will address some remarks on an article that appeared in the
West Australian
newspaper on Friday last, 22 November. Also I will relate those remarks to some others I made in this place in September of this year regarding the Royal Commission into the City of Wanneroo which is proceeding in Western Australia right now.

speech.para:
The article in the
West Australian
is entitled `Davis criticises MHR'. It starts:

Wanneroo royal commissioner Roger Davis has accused Labor MHR Stephen Smith of acting irresponsibly by using parliamentary privilege to reveal Mr Davis had suppressed evidence by accountant Laurie Fowler and then ordered that no reference be made to the suppression.
Mr Davis is quoted as saying:

I am not of course able to identify the reasons which applied in the case of Mr Fowler without
even further undermining the confidentiality I was seeking to enforce.
The article also states:

In his speech to the House on Monday, Mr Smith said the commission's decision raised very grave concerns for people interested in accountability. Mr Smith described Mr Davis' act of suppressing the suppression order as a "double banger"—and it is also a tongue twister.

One can understand why Mr Davis would not want to identify all his reasons for having taken the very unusual step of suppressing the fact that there had been a suppression order. But one would hope that his reasons for issuing that double‐banger suppression order are not related to the state election which is under way in Western Australia now. One would hope also that Mr Davis is not protecting Premier Richard Court's chief political adviser, Richard Elliott. One would hope, indeed, that that is not the case.

It is important to draw a distinction between what is happening in this particular matter with the suppression of Mr Fowler's evidence as opposed to what happened in the commission recently to the suppression of evidence given by the previous commissioner into Wanneroo, Mr Peter Kyle, and the again quite extraordinary actions by the commissioner in lifting that suppression order on the evidence given by Mr Kyle. Again, one would hope sincerely that Mr Davis has not been influenced by fact that there is an election going on in the state of Western Australia at this time and, indeed, by the fact that Mr Kyle happens to be a candidate in that election.

In the speech I gave some months ago, to which I have referred, I mentioned that Mr Kyle had previously criticised police in Western Australia for going soft on corruption, for not vigorously investigating politicians and for refusing to hand over documents necessary to his inquiry—and this was reported in the
West Australian
on 11 April 1996. Mr Kyle also had earlier stated in the
West Australian
newspaper on 17 February that `some of the same police figures alleged to be involved in the Argyle diamonds disappearance also were involved in Wanneroo' and that `people in the drug trade had connections with Wanneroo'.

break.para: This royal commission we have proceeding in Western Australia is truly extraordinary and it continues to be extraordinary. Not only are there the matters I have referred to tonight but there are also the actions of the commission and the effects of the commission to date which are of grave concern to the good citizens of Western Australia. One of the casualties of the commission so far has been the intelligence unit of the Ministry for Justice which is involved in the gathering of information about one David King. David King was convicted of corruption and gaoled, and some of his evidence was given to the commission.

Mr King was subject to an axe job by the counsel assisting the commission. But of greater concern was that it was said that her attacks had serious implications for the fight against crime and corruption generally because all law enforcement agencies at both state and federal level depend on the information flow. Miss Narelle Johnson was critical of the ministry's intelligence unit.

The officer in charge of certain investigations before the commission, Detective McLeod, told the commission that the Police Bureau of Criminal Intelligence had been informed of an association between convicted former mayor of Wanneroo Bradshaw and convicted drug runner Allan Harriman, what had been done about this and about the contacts between Bradshaw and well‐known criminal John Kizon.

The Royal Commissioner, Mr Davis, has decided not to require Harriman to give evidence because his information is outside the terms of reference. It seems to me that terms of reference can be particularly fluid from time to time as, indeed, it would appear that the use of suppression orders have been fluid from time to time, depending on who they are going to impact upon. But the matter of the intelligence unit and the impact of the commission on it is of importance. Previously it was staffed by eight people; it is now only going to be staffed by five people. Its name, of course, is also going to be changed. It is going to be called just the intelligence unit.

Part of the role of any intelligence unit is the gathering and collection of intelligence.
Part of the gathering and collection of intelligence occurs in prisons. We have already witnessed the impact of the reduction in staff and, indeed, the impact of the reduction in the gathering of information in the prisons in Western Australia. On one particular weekend—the weekend of 26 and 27 October, just a month ago—a total of 10 prisoners escaped from the Karnet and Wooroloo prison farms. There were five escapes from each of them. A total of 39 escapes have occurred in Western Australia in the financial year to date—that is, from 1 July this year. Intelligence unit staff are now not permitted to go into prisons to gather information from prisoners and/or staff. They are now reliant on information passed to them by security staff within each institution. It is well known that this system of information gathering does not work. Prisons have a history of not passing on information for fear that their prison will be criticised for poor management practices.

The restricted movement of intelligence staff in prisons will lead to the reduction of criminal intelligence being passed to police. This will mean that vital criminal intelligence is not gathered or passed to the appropriate law enforcement agencies. With the reduction in the number of intelligence staff, the intelligence unit will also cease its weekend coverage. It will no longer be able to provide a service to prisons and police during the weekends.

I suppose I too could be criticised by Commissioner Davis for giving out that information, but I suspect that those incarcerated in the prison system in Western Australia will know that their weekends are quite free to plan whatever they care to plan. Of course, when we talk about illicit drugs and the use of illicit substances within the prison system, one really has to be concerned that the intelligence system is not there to detect these things at the moment. The matter of the Wanneroo royal commission is of grave concern, but I suggest that the behaviour of the commissioner—and, indeed, counsel assisting—may indeed be of even graver concern in the long term for Western Australia and for the justice system of Australia.

Senator O'BRIEN
(Tasmania) (7.56 p.m.) This evening I rise to speak about the sale of Tasrail as part of the Australian National Rail sale which was announced on Sunday by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp). I noted the comments that were made by Senator Abetz today in taking note in relation to a criticism of the opposition with regard to questions asked in question time.

The issues that have been raised in relation to the statement by the minister regarding the sale are serious issues. One would have thought that the minister would have been keen to have had those issues properly tested by the scrutiny of parliament, and yet the minister announced this most important aspect of the business of the Australian transport industry on a Sunday leading into a week when the House of Representatives was not sitting. I understand we have the opportunity to ask questions of Senator Alston, who is representing the minister in the Senate. However, I do not think that is the desirable course of action; Minister Sharp is the appropriate person to be answering those questions. I think there are some questions that the minister needs to address himself to—and, no doubt, will—when the House of Representatives resumes next Monday.

I was amazed to hear Senator Abetz, who represents Tasmania, being so fulsome in his praise of the sale of Australian National and the National Rail Corporation given the position of Tasrail, the Tasmanian arm of Australian National. It is equally amazing that the Tasmanian government has abrogated its responsibility to Tasmania on this issue and supports Minister Sharp's plan for the sell‐off of Tasrail. According to today's
Examiner
newspaper, Tasmania is the only state in which the track—or, as it is more properly known, the permanent way—will most probably not remain in public ownership. There is some question about the land on which the rails lie, but that is not yet resolved. The question of even that aspect of the asset is up in the air.

I am advised that Tasrail lost $6.6 million in the last financial year. That compares with
losses in the 1980s of in excess of $15 million. When you factor those losses into today's dollars, you find that Tasrail's position has improved markedly following the restructure of Tasrail that the former Labor government set about achieving.

I understand, but have not had fully confirmed, that Tasrail's losses are in part due to the cost of servicing debt. It is interesting to note that the proposal that the minister has put before the public involves the federal government effectively taking upon itself and removing from the rail assets the total debt of $2 billion. If that debt is removed from Tasrail, then I suspect it becomes a profitable concern. However, given the sale is supported by the Tasmanian government, which is a minority government and does not have of its own right the ability to govern, and given that it is obviously the policy of the federal government, one must consider the possible implications for Tasmania of the sale.

It is, I suspect, probable that some of the lines and services will close, transferring the cargo carried on those lines to road freight. Every 100,000 tonnes transferred to the road equates to 72 tri‐axle truck movements per week. That is one way, assuming they go full one way and come back empty to their original loading point. If you consider that in terms of the B double or articulated truck systems, that is 46 truck movements both ways. Again, that assumes that the trucks are fully laden.

Transfer of course will therefore mean more pressure on the roads. Road damage is repaired at the cost of the state. Also, there are dangers and inconveniences caused to road users by the additional use by heavy vehicles of the Tasmanian road system. It is also probable that increased freight charges to rail users will occur, as any buyers seek to recover their purchase costs. That will have an impact upon the Tasmanian economy, but it also may have the impact of forcing further freight onto the road system on the basis of the cost competition between road and rail freight.

If you look at the totality of the picture, you will see that last year Tasrail carried 2,091,000 tonnes of freight. If you convert
that to tri‐axle or B double trucks, you find that it is suddenly between 980 and 1,400 additional truck movements per week, again both ways. If you look at what might happen, for example, in the transportation of coal from the Fingal Valley—and anyone in Tasmania who knows the road would be considering in horror the prospect of heavy truck movements carrying coal on that road—you see that there would need to be 80 additional truck movements each way each day to carry the 50 tonnes of coal that is carried out of there per day. In relation to the carriage of cement from Railton to Devonport—this is the most profitable line and it may be the most remote possibility—if it were transferred to a trucking system, it would involve one truck movement for every three minutes of the day.

So at its best, this proposal, this strategy, is a massive risk for Tasmania. If it does not come off, Tasmania will lose its rail services and hundreds of jobs. If it does not come off, there is the prospect of massive damage to the Tasmanian road system at the cost of the Tasmanian government to repair it. In addition, there will be a disincentive to the tourists who travel the state's roads. That is not a good thing for the tourism industry in Tasmania, given the events over the recent year and the fact that Tasmania is looking to rebuild its tourism industry. We are looking at the possibility of further carnage on Tasmanian highways as well.

The risk being taken in relation to Tasrail, if one separates that from the rest of the package, is unnecessary. Clearly Tasrail is able to be kept in public hands and to operate profitably if the debt burden is removed from it. The Tasmanian government should demand that Tasrail be handed back debt free to be run by the Tasmanian government in the interests of the Tasmanian people. That is an equitable solution. In relation to this sale, there is a case to be made for separating Tasrail from the rest of the rail assets.

—I rise tonight to speak about the announcement by Mr Peter Reith today of Public Service reform, a discussion paper which he has put out. The part of the discus
sion paper to which I wish to refer is a section on page 18, which talks about the age at which people in the Public Service are required to retire. The discussion paper says:

speech.para: The Workplace Relations legislation will outlaw discrimination in employment on a number of grounds, including age, membership or non-membership of a union and family responsibilities. Consistent with the principle of non-discrimination, the government intends to repeal compulsory age 65 retirement—an issue where, under Labor, the Commonwealth lagged behind other jurisdictions.

All I can say is alleluia to that. I have been campaigning in this chamber for years to see that reform and I welcome the announcement that Mr Reith made in that discussion paper. The days when capable, productive and vastly experienced employees are told to quit merely because they have reached a certain age will soon be a thing of the past. I have been approached in the corridors of this place by a number of people, including public servants, since I brought in my first private member's bill. They have asked me what is happening about this.

As I have said here a number of times, it is not as if we will be overwhelmed by the number of people over age 65 wanting to stay on. I have forgotten what the percentage is, but off the top of my head it will be a very small percentage. I stand to be corrected but about four per cent of public servants are over 64 years of age. There is not going to be a great flood of people wanting to stay on and thus taking jobs from younger people, but a number of people are capable of staying on and wish to do so. How ably people can do that is demonstrated by people in small business working till their middle or late 70s—and even later.

It seems to me inappropriate that in this day and age we have a retirement age in the Public Service. As I have said, I have campaigned against this inequity for many years. I have introduced two private member's bills—one in 1992 and another in 1995—and all the Labor Party could do was give excuse after excuse about why it was impossible to get rid of age discrimination. Older Australians are justifiably outraged at the existence of age discrimination. As I said, denying people the opportunity of employment based
solely on one's age without regard to their ability, qualifications or experience is no less offensive than discrimination on the basis of sex, race or religion.

All too often older Australians are betrayed and stereotyped as being frail, dependent, unwell, incapable of learning new skills, inflexible, unable to accept change, passive and unproductive. Those sorts of views and concepts will be thrown out the window. There is no arbitrary point in life where we can say someone is no longer a productive and worthwhile member of the work force. There is no discriminating age at which one can determine that someone is not capable of being productive in the work force.

The abolition of age discrimination has been part of coalition policy since 1988. Labor has dragged its feet on this issue for at least six years. The coalition has made concrete moves to address this, even though it has been in office since only 2 March, but I want to remind people of Labor's history on this matter.

In 1990, the Minister for Social Security, Graham Richardson, gave an undertaking to remove age discrimination from all existing federal legislation. That was never done despite an undertaking by a minister. In 1993, Senator Bolkus stated:
. . . the Attorney‐General's Department is working towards the development of a comprehensive Commonwealth age discrimination policy.

It was never done. We saw the resistance the Labor Party showed when time and again I moved amendments in this chamber to enable people serving on boards of statutory authorities to remain doing so after they were 65. One example is the National Maritime Museum. They said they were grateful I moved those amendments because a retired naval officer who was able to make major contributions to the museum was going to have to cease working with them and they wanted to still be able to call on his skills and abilities post age 65.

The only way we could overcome this type of situation was, when a bill that related to a statutory authority like the museum or various bodies of that ilk came forward, to systematically put an amendment to allow people aged
over 65 to serve on the board. Senator Baume and I religiously put that in every time one came up and gradually, bit by bit, we wore away the stone.

But Labor always found some problem—for example, if the person concerned fell over, what would we do about their compensation? There was always some petty excuse. They could not work out a way of overcoming these things. But it so happens that every state legislature except Tasmania has been able to do it. All states except Tasmania have enacted legislation to prohibit discrimination on the basis of age—the most recent being Victoria with the Equal Opportunity Act 1995. It was not a Labor government but a coalition government which enacted that.

It is disgraceful that the Commonwealth should be second last to enact this legislation and to enact this protection. It is particularly disgraceful that for so long the Commonwealth and the Labor Party tolerated discrimination against its own employees. We have lagged behind the rest of the world in this regard. Labor have ignored the moves that have taken place in many other legislatures around the world. On page 11 of the report of inquiry into complaints of discrimination in employment and occupation, dated 30 August this year, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner said:
I recommend that the Commonwealth legislate to provide a comprehensive national prohibition of age discrimination.
I wonder whether Chris Sidoti realised when he wrote that how quickly the government would move.

I call upon the Labor Party, the Greens, the Democrats and the Independents to give their full support to the amendment which will eliminate age discrimination in the Public Service. I hope Senator Barney Cooney's comments in this chamber the other day that people should not be discriminated against on the basis of age and that they should be allowed to work if they are capable of doing so signal a change of mind in the Labor Party.

When this reform is brought in, hopefully we will see a very quick move away from the inaction of the Labor Party and we will see
something being done for those who wish to continue to work and are assessed as being able to do so. I do not think we should indiscriminately permit people to continue working. Some sensible guidelines enabling review should be put in place to ensure that people do not stay on past the time they are still productive. I welcome the reform that Mr Reith has announced.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to outline an imaginative proposal by the government to create jobs in regional Australia. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is investigating a proposal to build two new Department of Social Security client service centres. The plan is to build these somewhere in regional Australia to create jobs there. The minister is communicating with state and territory governments to enlist their support and cooperation, so it is outrageous that the ALP government in New South Wales has strenuously rejected the minister's proposals. Chances to win regional jobs for New South Wales have been knocked on the head by the state Labor government. That will put those of us in New South Wales' rural and regional cities at a great disadvantage.

speech.para: Minister Newman's proposal had two key elements. The Department of Social Security was going to build one or two hub centres in regional Australia. They were going to be manned by 200 staff to service the telephone inquiries of the department's clients. Of course, with advances in the information superhighway and the roll‐out of optic fibre around Australia, it really does not matter where you put these sorts of centres. Traditionally we have tended to put these things in the centre of the big cities. With the new technology, this is no longer necessary.

As the United States examples have shown us, you can often drive the taxpayer's dollar quite a lot further if you put such centres in regional areas, where the land is cheaper and there is often an available, quite willing and skilled labour force—that is certainly the case in my area—to take advantage of such a proposal. To support this arrangement, each state government was asked to indicate the
level of assistance that they were prepared to put towards such a project by way of grants or other incentives to attract the Department of Social Security to a regional city. It was suggested that this support could be in the form of fitting out premises and free rent periods and could involve staff transport costs and the costs of furnishing and equipment. A bidding process to force such efficiencies and save taxpayers' money was to be undertaken to encourage the state and territory governments to play a constructive role in regional development.

So what has been the response of the New South Wales ALP government to this imaginative proposal? The Treasurer of that government, Michael Egan, has guaranteed single‐handedly that another major investment will not be going to New South Wales. Mr Egan is again turning his back on rural and regional Australia, and possible job creation projects in areas such as Newcastle and Maitland are now at risk. Labor, both at the federal and state levels, appears incapable of learning the lesson that people in regions such as the Hunter want support, not sabotage, for investment proposals such as this.

The DSS proposal would be ideally located in the Hunter region, which has very high youth unemployment and a skilled population that could quite easily fill the 200 positions available. We have sites in the region, such as the better cities Honeysuckle development in Newcastle, and certainly ones in Maitland as an alternative. If the New South Wales ALP government is serious about attracting jobs to the Hunter, it should at least consider Senator Newman's proposal.

My colleague the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Baldwin) and I will not be deterred by Mr Egan's playing politics. We will seek urgent discussions with the Minister for Social Security to ensure that the Hunter region is listed as a possible location for the Department of Social Security's hub service centre. In the meantime, we will continue to expose the ALP as the party that is sabotaging job creation in the Hunter region and other parts of New South Wales.

oil spill (January 1996) reveals that only 7.5 tonnes (or 2.3 per cent) of the 325 tonnes spilt was recovered from the sea, and given that this amounts to 97.7 per cent ineffectiveness of the National Oil Spill Plan for a comparatively small spill, (but is not surprising given that recoveries of more than 10 per cent are unusual in the world for spills near coastlines or in enclosed waters): In view of this lamentable failure, how can the national plan to combat pollution of the sea by oil as it applies to Western Port Bay (or the related, Australian Marine Safety Authority approved, Shell-Mobil oil spill prevention and response plan) be regarded as providing adequate protection of the important wetland values of the bay for which the Australian Government has responsibilities under the Ramsar, JapanAustralia Migratory Birds Agreement and China-Australia Migratory Birds Agreement treaties.

(5) (a) Did the Minister, in May 1996, meet with community representatives on Phillip Island and was the Minister presented with both on-site evidence and documentary evidence (so far completely unchallenged) to indicate the ecological sensitivity of Western Port Bay for the importation of crude oil; and (b) what steps have been taken to meet these concerns.

(6) Is the Minister aware that, whilst the Shell-Mobil project is still on hold (although fully approved by both State and Federal Governments and open implementation at any time), the importation of refined spirit by another company (Wickland) through the Crib Point jetty has been allowed to proceed despite the community's long-standing and well-documented concerns and requests for an open inquiry.

(7) Is the Minister aware that, in March 1994, the Council of the (former) Shire of Hastings resolved unanimously `That in light of existing decisions of the State Government not to require an EES/EIS for the project, the PMA and the Federal Government be requested to require that an EES/EIS be prepared for the Crib Point Terminal and other current and future oil and refined product importation projects within Western Port Bay before these facilities come into operation, as highlighted by Council's review and suggested in earlier port planning studies conducted by the PMA', and that the recommendations made at this time by Hastings
Council have subsequently been supported by its successor, the Mornington Peninsula Shire Council, in correspondence to the previous Minister for the Environment.

(8) In light of the strong expressions of both local government and community concern, and bearing in mind the Government's Ramsar and other obligations, what inquiries or actions regarding the Wickland operation have been undertaken by the Commonwealth Government.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The quote referred to in the question is taken from Appendix 1 of Australia's National Report to the Sixth Ramsar Conference. The quote was based on comments by non-government organisations consulted when the report was being prepared.

(2) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) received a letter from the Secretary General of the Ramsar Convention Bureau on 5 July 1996, regarding the possible inclusion of Western Port Bay on the Montreux Record.
(3) I discussed the issue of Western Port Bay with staff of the Ramsar Bureau when I visited there on 16 July 1996.

(4) In recognition of the environmental values to Western Port Bay, I have requested that my Department provide me with advice on options, which the Commonwealth could consider, to assist the Victorian Government with their future management of oil handling in that State.
(5) (a) Yes
(b) I am currently receiving advice on the best way to respond to the concerns.
(6) Yes. I am aware that the Wickland proposal was assessed under the EPIP Act in February of this year and that no EIS or PER was required.

(7) My Department received correspondence dated 22 March 1994 from the Westernport and Peninsula Protection Council Inc attaching a copy of the resolution from the Hastings Shire Council calling for the Federal Government to conduct an EIA. My Department has no records of the former Minister for the Environment receiving a subsequent letter from the Mornington Peninsula Shire Council on this issue.
(8) Please see answer to question 4 above.
